questions.text: A child presents with bleeding gums and decreased wound healing. What is the reason for these findings?
questions.solution:
This patient has easy bleeding/bruising and gingivitis (Swollen and bleeding gums), findings indicative of vitamin C deficiency (Scurvy).

  • Vitamin C (Ascorbic Acid) is a required cofactor for the hydroxylation of proline and lysine by prolyl and lysyl hydroxylases, respectively, during collagen synthesis.
  • Impaired hydroxylation in vitamin C deficiency compromises collagen's tensile strength, increasing capillary wall fragility and causing petechiae/ecchymoses, mucosal bleeding (eg, nosebleeds), and perifollicular hemorrhages.  Periodontal disease (gingival erythema/edema/bleeding) and hyperkeratotic follicles (due to keratin plugging) with coiled/corkscrew hairs are also common features. 

Reference: Harpar’s illustrated Biochemistry, 31th Edition, Page. No- 540

questions.text: A patient has diarrhea, dermatitis and dementia. This indicates a deficiency of?
questions.solution:
Pellagra is due to niacin deficiency and is characterized by 3 Ds: dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia (the 4th D being death):

  • Dermatitis is bilateral and symmetric on sun-exposed areas of the body and is characterized by rough, thick, scaly skin.
  • Diarrhea is due to atrophy (and occasional ulceration) of the columnar epithelium of the gastrointestinal tract.
  • Dementia is due to neuronal degeneration in the brain and spinal cord, with lesions like those associated with pernicious anemia.


Reference: Harpar’s illustrated Biochemistry, 31th Edition, Page. No- 534,538.

questions.text:
A patient presented with alopecia, skin rash and ulcer. He has a diet mainly consisting of raw egg white. Which nutrient deficiency is associated with this condition?

1. Niacin
2. Thiamine
3. Pyridoxine
4. Biotin
questions.solution:
Biotin deficiency is rare but can occur secondary to poor diet, excessive raw egg white consumption (due to high levels of biotin-binding avidin in egg whites), and congenital disorders of biotin metabolism.

  • Patients with biotin deficiency present with nonspecific symptoms, including changes in mental status, myalgias, anorexia, and chronic dermatologic changes such as macular dermatitis.
  • Biotin-deficient individuals can also develop metabolic acidosis as a result of increased conversion of pyruvate to lactic acid.
  • Apart from such individuals or those maintained on total parenteral nutrition for many months, biotin deficiency is virtually unknown.

Reference: Harpar’s illustrated Biochemistry, 31th Edition, Page. No- 538.

questions.text: What is the most probable vitamin deficiency anticipated in a pregnant women who is on strict vegetarian diet?
questions.solution:
Vitamin B12 (cobalamin) is primarily found in animal-derived foods such as meat, eggs, and dairy products.

Key points:

  • Strict vegetarians (vegans) are at high risk of B12 deficiency because plant-based foods generally do not provide adequate B12.

  • Pregnancy increases B12 requirements, so deficiency can lead to:

    • Maternal: Megaloblastic anemia, fatigue, glossitis

    • Fetal: Neural tube defects, developmental delays, low birth weight

  • Other B vitamins:

    • B6, B1, and B5 are widely available in plant foods and are less likely to be deficient in a vegetarian diet.

questions.text: Which of the following micronutrient deficiency is associated with hypogonadism
questions.solution:
• Zinc deficiency causes decreased sexual maturation and hypogonadism.
  • Other features of zinc deficiency include (1) Poor physical growth (2) anemia (3) anorexia (3) alopecia (4) impaired immune function
  • Acrodermatitis enteropathica is an autosomal recessive disorder of severe zinc deficiency, caused by impaired intestinal absorption due to a defect in intestinal zinc transporter protein.
  • It presents in early infancy with vesiculobullous, dry, scaly, or eczematous skin lesions chiefly in the periorificial and acral areas.
Reference: Prasad AS, Mantzoros CS, Beck FW, Hess JW, Brewer GJ. Zinc status and serum testosterone levels of healthy adults. Nutrition. 1996 May;12(5):344-8. doi: 10.1016/s0899-9007(96)80058-x. PMID: 8875519.

choices.text: Increased levels of homocysteine and methylmalonic acid
Folate deficiency is commonly seen in children with hemolytic anemia
Periconceptional folate supplements, begin 3 months before conception and continued for 1 month after conception to reduce neural tube defects
It is important to treat co-existing vitamin B12 deficiency before initiating folate therapy

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding folate deficiency?
questions.solution:
• Folic acid plays a key role in one-carbon metabolism, essential for the biosynthesis of several compounds.
  • Tetrahydrofolate (THF), the reduced, coenzyme form of folate, receives one-carbon fragments from donors such as serine, glycine, and histidine and transfers them to intermediates in the synthesis of amino acids, purine nucleotides, and thymidine monophosphate.
  • Folate deficiency is caused by increased demand (e.g., pregnancy and lactation), poor absorption caused by pathology of the small intestine, alcoholism, or treatment with drugs (e.g., methotrexate) that are dihydrofolate reductase inhibitors. It is seen in children with macrocytic anemia.

Folate deficiency causes
(1)Anemia -due to diminished synthesis of purine nucleotides and TMP, which leads to an inability of cells to make DNA and, therefore, an inability to divide.
(2)Neural tube defects : in order to prevent these defects Peri-conceptional folate supplements is begun 1 month before conception and continued for 3 months after.
(3) Hyperhomocysteinemia - Folate, along with vitamin B12, is involved in converting homocysteine to methionine. Hence folate deficiency causes increased levels of homocysteine.

Reference: Vasudevan textbook of Biochemistry, 8th Edition, Page No 475-479.

questions.text: Xanthurenic aciduria is seen in which of the following vitamin deficiency?
questions.solution:
Xanthurenic aciduria is seen in deficiency of vitamin B6 (pyridoxal phosphate), a coenzyme required by kynureninase enzyme to convert 3-OH kynurenine to 3-OH anthranilic acid during tryptophan metabolism.

 

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st edition, Page no 288,533-538 .

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely to cause Beriberi?
questions.solution:
Overview of Beriberi
Cause: Beriberi is caused by a prolonged deficiency of thiamine (Vitamin B1). Key dietary sources of thiamine include yeast, organ meats, whole grains (especially the aleurone layer), legumes, beef, and nuts. It's important to note that thiamine can be partially destroyed by heat during cooking.

Risk Factors for Thiamine Deficiency
Thiamine deficiency is more prevalent among:
  • Individuals who consume alcohol chronically
  • Patients with chronic illnesses, such as cancer
  • Those on long-term diuretic therapy
  • Individuals who have undergone bariatric surgery
  • Women experiencing prolonged hyperemesis gravidarum
  • People consuming a diet primarily based on polished rice
  • Consumption of certain foods that can inactivate thiamine, such as shellfish, coffee, tea, and betel nuts
Symptoms of Prolonged Thiamine Deficiency
Wet Beriberi: Characterized by symptoms including an enlarged heart, tachycardia, high-output congestive heart failure, peripheral edema, and peripheral neuritis.
Dry Beriberi: Associated with neurological symptoms such as peripheral neuropathy, optic atrophy, ataxia, and irritability.
Wernicke's Encephalopathy: Typically observed in chronic alcoholics, this condition presents with horizontal nystagmus, ophthalmoplegia, cerebellar ataxia, and cognitive impairment. If accompanied by memory loss and confabulation, it is referred to as Wernicke-Korsakoff Syndrome.

Diagnosis
The diagnosis of thiamine deficiency can be confirmed through the assessment of erythrocyte transketolase activity.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male whose staple diet primarily consisted of only maize presents with diarrhea, dementia, and photosensitive dermatitis in sun-exposed areas. Which vitamin is most likely deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
The history and clinical features indicate a niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency.

Excessive consumption of maize-based diets can lead to niacin deficiency, as maize contains niacin in a bound form that is not easily absorbed. Additionally, jowar (sorghum) is high in leucine, which inhibits the enzyme QPRTase, involved in niacin synthesis.

Niacin deficiency results in the condition known as pellagra, which is characterized by the classic triad of:

Diarrhea
Dermatitis
Dementia
A hallmark sign of pellagra is Casal's necklace, an erythematous and pigmented rash in the distribution of a broad collar around the neck.



Pellagra can develop even with sufficient intake of tryptophan and niacin in conditions such as:

Carcinoid syndrome, where tryptophan is diverted to serotonin production.
Hartnup disease, due to defective tryptophan transport, resulting in malabsorption and impaired renal reabsorption.
Niacin also plays a role in lipid metabolism by significantly reducing levels of apoB-containing lipoproteins (VLDL, IDL, LDL, and lipoprotein(a)) and increasing HDL cholesterol.

Niacin toxicity can occur when taken in excessive amounts for hyperlipidemia management, leading to:

Prostaglandin-mediated cutaneous flushing
Glucose intolerance
Fulminant hepatitis (the most serious complication)
Hyperuricemia
Macular edema and macular cysts.

questions.text: A male patient presented with complaints of imbalance, numbness of the foot, and muscle weakness. On history taking, he revealed that he has been taking multivitamin tablets more than the prescribed dose for 1 year. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the associated symptoms seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette suggests a diagnosis of vitamin B6 toxicity due to excessive intake of vitamin B6 supplements.

The active form of vitamin B6, also known as pyridoxine, is pyridoxal phosphate (PLP). PLP serves as a coenzyme in numerous biological reactions, including transaminations, decarboxylations, metabolism of sulfur-containing amino acids, heme synthesis, niacin synthesis, and glycogenolysis.

Several drugs can decrease pyridoxine levels, including isoniazid, cycloserine, oral contraceptives, and alcohol. Deficiency in vitamin B6 can lead to various manifestations, such as convulsions, peripheral neuritis, pellagra (due to impaired niacin synthesis), and hypochromic microcytic anemia (resulting from inhibited heme synthesis). Vitamin B6 levels can be assessed through the erythrocyte transaminase assay.

It is important to note that excessive intake from food sources does not cause toxicity; toxicity is primarily associated with supratherapeutic doses of supplements exceeding 100-200 mg/day or cases of iatrogenic overdose. Symptoms of pyridoxine toxicity may include neurological effects such as numbness, tingling, muscle weakness, and in severe cases, difficulty in ambulation.

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme is found to be deficient in Von Gierke's disease?
questions.solution:
Von Gierke's disease, also known as Glycogen Storage Disease Type I, is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase, which plays a crucial role in glucose metabolism by converting glucose-6-phosphate to free glucose. It is an autosomal recessive disorder that leads to the accumulation of glycogen in organs like the liver and kidneys.

Clinical Presentation:
Infancy onset (typically around 3-4 months of age)
Hepatomegaly (enlarged liver) and hypoglycemic seizures are common early signs.
Children may have doll-like faces due to chubby cheeks, thin extremities, short stature, and a protuberant abdomen caused by hepatomegaly.
Enlarged kidneys are also present.
Easy bruising and epistaxis (nosebleeds) due to prolonged bleeding times.
Other potential complications include delayed puberty, polycystic ovaries, osteopenia, pancreatitis, neutropenia, hepatic adenoma, and various renal diseases.

Laboratory Findings:
Hypoglycemia
Lactic acidosis
Ketosis
Hyperuricemia (elevated uric acid levels)
Hyperlipidemia
These clinical and lab features guide the diagnosis, which can be confirmed via liver biopsy or gene-based variant analysis.

Treatment:
The goal is to maintain normal blood glucose levels:
Nasogastric infusion of glucose or uncooked cornstarch for infants.
Uncooked cornstarch can be given orally to older children.
Dietary restrictions include avoiding fructose and galactose.
Orthotopic liver transplantation may be a curative option in certain cases.

questions.text: Which of the following is given to prevent neural tube defects?
questions.solution:
Folic acid (Vitamin B9) is given to prevent the incidence of neural tube defects. Folic acid deficiency is implicated in neural tube defects like spina bifida, encephalocele, and anencephaly.
Supplementation of folic acid, in doses of 400 g/day, prior to conception has been shown to cause a significant reduction in the incidence of spina bifida and other neural tube defects.
Reduced activity of the enzyme 5, 10-methylene-THF reductase (MTHFR) caused by a common C677T polymorphism in the MTHFR gene is one of the causes of neural tube defects in folate deficiency. Ref-Goodman & Gillman's The Pharmacological Basis Of Therapeutics - 13th Edition • Page no: 766

questions.text: A 70 year old woman who consumes a maize rich diet presented with abnormal behavioural, forgetfulness diarrhoea and the following skin rash. Identify the given condition
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of diarrhoea, dementia, abnormal behaviour and photosensitive rash present around the neck is suggestive of vitamin B3 deficiency also known as pellagra.
Niacin deficiency results in the condition of pellagra, which, although uncommon in industrialized nations, may be seen in individuals living in poverty or those with extremely low niacin and protein-deficient diets. The initial symptoms of pellagra include loss of appetite, generalized weakness, irritability, abdominal pain, and vomiting. This is followed by bright red glossitis (beefy tongue) and a characteristic pigmented, scaly skin rash in sun-exposed areas. This rash is known as Casal's necklace when it forms a ring around the neck.
The 4 D's of pellagra are Diarrhea, Dermatitis, Dementia, and if untreated, Death.
It is diagnosed by measuring urinary levels of 2-methyl nicotinamide and
2-pyridone. It is treated by oral supplementation of 100-200 mg of nicotinamide or nicotinic acid three times daily for 5 days.Ref- Harpers illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Page 528,534

questions.text: A patient is brought with symptoms of diarrhea, hair loss, and poor wound healing. Which mineral deficiency is responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
The clinical signs and symptoms are suggestive of acrodermatitis enteropathica, caused due to zinc deficiency
A zinc-absorbing transmembrane protein deficiency causes this autosomal recessive condition.

Important signs and symptoms consist of:
  1. slowing of growth
  2. diarrhea
  3. Alopecia
  4. rash with vesicular and pustular crusting, scaling, and erythema that affects the face, limbs, and perineum
  5. Atrophy of the gonads
  6. delayed healing of wounds


Other options:
  1. Magnesium- Causes neuromuscular symptoms (tetany, seizures, arrhythmias)
  2. Niacin (Vitamin B3) –  Pellagra: diarrhea, dementia, dermatitis
  3. Vitamin C - Scurvy: bleeding gums, poor wound healing


Reference
1.Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry 30th Edition - Pg 564
2.Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics 20th Edition - Page no 3238

questions.text: Which of the following minerals help with stabilization of insulin secretion?
questions.solution:
Zinc is well known for its ability to stabilize insulin secretion.

Zinc helps the beta cells of the pancreas to produce, store, and release insulin. Insulin is stored in the β-cells of the pancreas in the form of hexamers, which are stabilized by zinc ions. Zinc is also co-secreted with insulin and helps maintain crystalline structure inside secretory granules.

Zinc deficiency can affect the production and secretion of insulin, which may aggravate metabolic disorders like diabetes.

other options:
1. Copper: Cuproenzymes, such ceruloplasmin, which support iron metabolism and antioxidant defense
2. Iron – Important in hemoglobin and electron transport
3. Cadmium: toxic heavy metal

Reference
Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd Edition - page 165, 166

questions.text: A patient, a known case of chronic alcoholism is brought to the emergency room with confusion and tremors. On examination, there is ataxia and ophthalmoplegia. Deficiency of which of the following is responsible for the condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical characteristics of this patient point to Wernicke's encephalopathy. It is a result of thiamine/vitamin B1 deficiency.

Classical triad (Mnemonic - GOA):
Global confusion
Ophthalmoplegia (the initial symptom that improves after an infusion of thiamine and dextrose)
Ataxia
 

Pathophysiology:
Thiamine is a coenzyme in:
1. Pyruvate dehydrogenase
2. α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
3. Branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase
4. Transketolase (in the pentose phosphate pathway)

In deficiency: reduced ATP production in neurons - Affects mammillary bodies, thalamus, and cerebellum

Always give thiamine before glucose in alcoholics — giving glucose first can worsen the encephalopathy (because this causes diversion of remaining thiamine into metabolism of glucose, worsening symptoms)

other options:
1. Vitamin B12 – Also causes neurological issues, but more like subacute combined degeneration (posterior column and corticospinal tract) — no ophthalmoplegia
2. Vitamin D – Bone-related symptoms
3. Vitamin C – Deficiency causes scurvy, with bleeding gums and poor wound healing



Reference:
Kaplan and Sadocks Synopsis of Psychiatry - 11th Edition, Page no: 632, 736

questions.text: Which of the following steps in the metabolism of Vitamin D requires sunlight?
questions.solution:
Sunlight is necessary for the metabolism of vitamin D in order to convert 7-dehydrocholesterol to cholecalciferol.

Three processes make up the metabolism of vitamin D:

Step 1: Skin: When exposed to UV light, 7-dehydrocholesterol, an intermediary in the synthesis of cholesterol that builds up in the skin, undergoes a nonenzymatic process that produces cholecalciferol, which is taken into the bloodstream. Keep in mind that cholecalciferol and 7-Dehydrocholesterol already have one hydroxy group.

Step 2: Liver: 25hydroxycholecalciferol is produced by hydroxylating cholecalciferol. This is released into the bloodstream attached to a globulin that binds vitamin D, the primary form of the vitamin that is stored.

Step 3: Kidney The enzyme 1ahydroxylase changes 25-hydroxycholecalciferol into 1,25 dihydroxycholecalciferol, which is the physiologically active form.
Sunlight is necessary for the metabolism of vitamin D in order to convert 7-dehydrocholesterol to cholecalciferol.


Reference: Harper's illustrated Biochemistry 31st edition page no 530-531

questions.text: Menke's disease is due to a deficiency of
questions.solution:
Menke's disease: 

  • Cause: Copper deficiency

  • Type: X-linked recessive disorder

  • Gene: Mutation in the ATP7A gene (copper-transporting ATPase)

    Pathophysiology:

  • Impaired intestinal absorption of copper

  • Low serum copper and ceruloplasmin levels

  • Copper is essential for enzymes like lysyl oxidase, cytochrome c oxidase, and tyrosinase



Reference: Harper's illustrated Biochemistry 31st edition page no 595-table 50-3

questions.text: A 34-year-old male was on maize as a staple diet for a prolonged period. He presented with pain abdomen, loss of appetite, and diarrhea. On examination, there was glossitis and a pigmented rash in sun-exposed areas. A lesion over his neck was seen as shown in the image below. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Clues from the case:

  • Maize-based diet → low in niacin and tryptophan

  • Symptoms:

    • Pain abdomen, diarrhea, loss of appetite

    • Glossitis

    • Pigmented rash in sun-exposed areas (photosensitive dermatitis)

    • Lesion over the neck: Casal's necklace → classic sign of pellagra



The illustration depicts the Casal's necklace pattern or Casal collar, a medical sign characterized by a red, pigmented skin rash that forms a wide collar (dermatomes C3 and C4).

A lack of niacin leads to pellagra, primarily affecting individuals on corn or maize-based diets that are deficient in both niacin and tryptophan.

The body can produce niacin from tryptophan. The two forms, nicotinic acid, and nicotinamide, act as precursors to niacin.

Its roles include:

* The nicotinamide part of the coenzymes NAD and NADP are involved in oxidation/reduction reactions.
* NAD is the source of ADPribose for the ADPribosylation of proteins and poly ADP ribosylation of nucleoproteins for DNA repair.

The early signs of pellagra include a loss of appetite, widespread weakness, irritability, abdominal pain, and vomiting. This is followed by a bright red glossitis and a characteristic pigmented, scaly skin rash in areas exposed to the sun.
This rash, known as Casal's necklace, encircles the neck in severe cases.
The main symptoms are often referred to as the 4 Ds: diarrhea, dermatitis, dementia, and death.

The diagnosis is made by checking the levels of 2methyl nicotinamide and 2-pyridone in the urine.

Treatment involves taking oral supplements of 100-200 mg of nicotinamide or nicotinic acid three times daily for five days.

Reference: Harper's illustrated Biochemistry 31st edition page no 534

questions.text: A young boy presented with fissured tongue, lips, and lesions in the angle of the mouth as shown below. On investigation, he had low RBC glutathione reductase activity. Which vitamin is deficient here?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture described — fissured tongue, cheilitis (cracks at the corners of the mouth), angular stomatitis, and glossitis — along with low RBC glutathione reductase activity, is characteristic of Riboflavin (Vitamin B2) deficiency.

The following symptoms and indicators indicate a riboflavin deficiency:
1. Cheilosis: paleness in the mouth's angle and lip fissure that radiates to the skin
2. Glossitis: loss of papilla (magenta-colored tongue) and smoothing of the tongue
3. Eye conditions: corneal vascularization, conjunctivitis, and keratitis
4. Additional attributes Anemia and seborrheic dermatitis When FAD is introduced in vitro, the activity of RBC glutathione reductase can be measured to determine the nutritional status of riboflavin (this test is specific for riboflavin deficiency).

Other options: 

  • Biotin: Deficiency causes dermatitis, alopecia, and neurologic symptoms, but not fissured tongue or cheilitis.

  • Vitamin B12: Causes megaloblastic anemia and neurological symptoms.

  • Vitamin B3 (Niacin): Deficiency causes pellagra (diarrhea, dermatitis, dementia), not the classic glossitis + angular cheilitis seen here.



Reference: Harper's illustrated Biochemistry 31st edition page no 534

choices.text: Vitamin B9 (Folic acid) : FIGLU excretion/ Histidine load test.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamins is wrongly matched with their associated enzymes?
questions.solution:
1. Vitamin B2 - RBC Glutathione reductase 

 

  • Riboflavin (B2) is a precursor of FAD, which is a coenzyme for glutathione reductase.

  • Measurement of RBC glutathione reductase activity helps assess riboflavin status.

    2. Vitamin B9 (Folic acid) – FIGLU excretion / Histidine load test 

  • Correctly matched.

  • Folic acid is required for one-carbon metabolism.

  • In folate deficiency, formiminoglutamic acid (FIGLU) accumulates after histidine load due to impaired conversion to glutamate.

  • Thus, FIGLU excretion increases in folate deficiency.

    3. Vitamin C – Serum methyl malonate level 

  • Wrongly matched.

  • Methylmalonic acid (MMA) levels are used to assess Vitamin B12 deficiency, not Vitamin C.

  • Vitamin C is assessed by plasma or leukocyte ascorbic acid levels.

    4. Vitamin B1 (Thiamine) – RBC transketolase 

  • Correctly matched.

  • Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP), the active form of B1, is a coenzyme for transketolase, an enzyme in the pentose phosphate pathway.

  • RBC transketolase activity is a sensitive test for thiamine deficiency.


Reference: Harper's illustrated Biochemistry 31st edition page 536

questions.text: The deficiency of vitamin B2 (riboflavin) can be assessed by measuring the activity of14. __
questions.solution:
• Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin) is a precursor of the coenzymes:

    • FMN (flavin mononucleotide)

    • FAD (flavin adenine dinucleotide)

  • Glutathione reductase is a FAD-dependent enzyme, and its activity in red blood cells (RBCs) is used to assess riboflavin status.

    Other Options:

  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase → requires thiamine (B1), lipoic acid, FAD, NAD, and CoA.

  • Transketolase → requires thiamine (B1); used to assess B1 deficiency.

  • Isocitrate dehydrogenase → uses NAD⁺ or NADP⁺, not a primary indicator for B2 deficiency.

    Enzymes Used to Assess Vitamin Deficiencies:
     

  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase → Thiamine (Vit B1)

  • Transketolase → Thiamine (Vit B1)

  • Succinate dehydrogenase → Riboflavin (Vit B2, FAD)

  • Acyl-CoA dehydrogenase → Riboflavin (Vit B2, FAD)

  • Dehydrogenases (general, e.g., lactate dehydrogenase) → Niacin (Vit B3, NAD⁺/NADP⁺)

  • Carboxylases (e.g., pyruvate carboxylase, acetyl-CoA carboxylase) → Biotin (Vit B7)

  • Transaminases (ALT, AST) → Pyridoxine (Vit B6, PLP)

  • Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase → Cobalamin (Vit B12)

  • Thymidylate synthase → Folate (Vit B9, THF)

Reference: Harper's illustrated Biochemistry 31st edition page no 534

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman who was on a diet consisting predominantly of packaged and reheated meals presents with iron-deficiency anemia, painful and tender joints, and bleeding manifestations. Which of the following antioxidant deficiency can lead to these symptoms?
questions.solution:
A diet of predominantly packaged and reheated meals lacks fresh fruits and vegetables, which are the main sources of vitamin C. Deficiency of vitamin C leads to scurvy, characterized by:

  • Iron-deficiency anemia: due to impaired iron absorption (vitamin C reduces ferric to ferrous iron for better absorption).

  • Joint pain and tenderness: from bleeding into joints due to defective collagen synthesis.

  • Bleeding manifestations: such as bleeding gums, petechiae, and ecchymoses, due to weak blood vessels and impaired wound healing.

    General Features of Scurvy:

  • Fatigue and malaise (early symptom)

  • Anemia, often iron-deficiency type

  • Poor wound healing

  • Bleeding gums, loose teeth

  • Petechiae, ecchymoses (especially on legs)

  • Corkscrew hairs (twisted hair shafts)

  • Perifollicular hemorrhages

  • Joint pain and swelling (due to bleeding into joints)

  • Subperiosteal hemorrhages (bone tenderness, common in children)

  • Swollen, bleeding gums (especially in adults with teeth)

  • Impaired collagen synthesis (defective hydroxylation of proline and lysine)

The other options do not explain the full constellation of symptoms:

  • β-carotene (vitamin A precursor): deficiency causes night blindness, not bleeding or anemia.

  • Zinc: deficiency causes poor wound healing and skin issues but not bleeding or anemia.

  • Glutathione: intracellular antioxidant, but its deficiency doesn’t lead to this clinical picture.


Reference: Harper's illustrated Biochemistry 31st edition page no 98,114,186,187,540,528 table 44-1

questions.text: A 10-year-old child from a southern Indian state, hailing from a poor family, presents with rough and scaly skin. The child's diet lacks vegetables and fruits. After treatment with linseed oil, Vitamin A, and Vitamin B, the symptoms subsided. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The cutaneous lesions with rough and scaly skin, with dietary history stating lack of vegetables and fruits is suggestive of phrynoderma.
  • Phrynoderma are keratotic follicular papules commonly present over the elbows and knees.
  • They can also extend to the shoulders, neck, back, thighs, buttocks, and abdomen. It is also known as toad skin, due to the rough cone-shaped elevated papules. It can caused by deficiency of vitamins A, B complex, C, and E and essential fatty acids.
Reference: Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page No 63.7.

choices.text: Increased CSF lactate is associated with a good prognosis

questions.text: After a severe brain injury, all of the following changes in brain metabolism are true, with the exception of the following:
questions.solution:
Pyruvate dehydrogenase activity (specifically E-1 subunit) declines after brain parenchymal damage - this causes lactate to accumulate in the brain and CSF and increases lactate absorption from circulation.
Hence statements (1),(2),(3) are correct.
Higher the CSF Lactate - the more the damage - the poorer the prognosis. 
The prognosis is better when CSF lactate levels reduce early in the disease.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 139.

questions.text: Which vitamin from the list below is necessary for glycogen phosphorylase?
questions.solution:
Pyridoxal phosphate is the cofactor of glycogen phosphorylase, where the phosphate group is catalytically important.

Pyridoxal phosphate is a coenzyme for a variety of enzymes, including those involved in the transamination and decarboxylation of amino acids. It serves as a cofactor for the enzyme glycogen phosphorylase, whose catalytic role is supplied by the phosphate group. Vitamin  B6 is also crucial for the activity of steroid hormones.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 166.

questions.text: A 12 month old infant who presented to pediatric emergency was found to have hepatomegaly, build up of limit dextrin and hypoglycemia. What condition is he likely to have?
questions.solution:
Above mentioned features are characteristics of Cori's disease, a type IIIa glycogen storage disorder (Forbes disease), caused by a lack of the debranching enzyme.
Type Name Deficient Enzyme Key Specific Features
Type I Von Gierke Disease Glucose-6-phosphatase Severe fasting hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, lactic acidosis
Type II Pompe Disease Lysosomal acid α-glucosidase Cardiomegaly, muscle weakness, "floppy baby" (infantile form)
Type III Cori Disease Debranching enzyme (α-1,6-glucosidase) Milder hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, accumulation of limit dextrin
Type IV Andersen Disease Branching enzyme Hepatosplenomegaly, liver cirrhosis, early death
Type V McArdle Disease Muscle glycogen phosphorylase Exercise intolerance, muscle cramps, myoglobinuria (red urine)
Type VI Hers Disease Liver glycogen phosphorylase Mild fasting hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 167.

questions.text: Between glycogenolysis and glycogenesis, which of the following enzymes is common?
questions.solution:
As phosphoglucomutase catalyzes a reversible process, glucose I-phosphate can be converted to glucose 6-phosphate.

Glucose 6-phosphatase then hydrolyzes glucose 6-phosphate in the liver (and kidney), but not in muscle, producing glucose that is released in blood that raises blood glucose levels.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 165.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presented to the OPD with complaints of hepatosplenomegaly and bone discomfort. The biopsy sample from the spleen revealed the cells of having  crumpled tissue paper appearance. Which product from the list below is most likely to have accumulated?
questions.solution:
The history of bone pain with hepatosplenomegaly, along with the appearance of crumpled tissue paper on biopsy, strongly points to Gaucher's disease.

The tissue enzyme Glucocerebrosidase, which separates glucose from glucosyl ceramide, is absent in Gaucher's disease.

Therefore, there is buildup of glucocerebrosides in peripheral tissues. 

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 235.

questions.text: In the state of fasting, which of the following is utilised by RBCs?
questions.solution:
As RBC lack mitochondria which is necessary for utilization of ketone body and fatty acid,  they can only use glucose as their source of energy.


Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 136.

questions.text: Which of these generates 3 ATPs per unit of glucose consumed during anaerobic glycolysis?
questions.solution:
Under anaerobic conditions, breakdown of glycogen generates 3 ATPs. Breakdown of glycogen generates glucose-6-phosphate which directly enters the glycolytic pathway. Thus, it bypasses the first ATP consuming step of glycolysis which is conversion of glucose to gluvose-6-phosphate. Therefore, one ATP is saved and anerobic glycolysis yields 3 ATPs rather than 2 ATPs.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 158.

questions.text: In which of the following is a low insulin-to-glucagon ratio not seen?
questions.solution:
• Glycogen synthesis: This process occurs when there is an abundance of glucose, typically after a meal when insulin levels are high. Insulin promotes the uptake of glucose into cells and stimulates the synthesis of glycogen. Therefore, glycogen synthesis is associated with a high insulin-to-glucagon ratio.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 158.

questions.text: What is the respiratory quotient following a carbohydrate meal?
questions.solution:
Respiratory Quotient (RO) after a heavy carbohydrate meal is 1.

An increase in the respiratory quotient (the ratio of carbon dioxide produced to oxygen consumed), from around 0.8 in the preserved state to close to I, indicates that glucose is the main fuel for oxidation in the majority of tissues.
RQ=CO2 produced/O2 consumed
 
RQ Value Metabolic Fuel Examples
1.0 Carbohydrate metabolism Complete oxidation of glucose (e.g., exercise or carbohydrate-rich diet).
0.7 Fat metabolism Lipid oxidation (e.g., fasting or low-carb diet).
0.8 Protein metabolism Protein catabolism (e.g., starvation).
0.8–0.9 Mixed diet (normal conditions) A combination of carbohydrates, fats, and proteins.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 138.

choices.text: Increased conversion of fatty acid to acetyl CoA

questions.text: Which of the following will naturally take place in a type 1 diabetes patient's body when they complain of polyuria?
questions.solution:
In the body of the patient with DM-1 there is Increased conversion of fatty acid to acetyl CoA.
 
  • Reduced insulin levels result in reduced fatty acid synthesis and increased glucagon levels in people with type 1 diabetes.
  • Reduced acetyl CoA carboxylase activity results in decreased malonyl CoA,an allosteric inhibitor of CPT-I, the rate-limiting enzyme of beta-oxidation, as a result of decreasing insulin levels.
  • Hence, unchecked beta-oxidation causes an increase in the conversion of fatty acids to acetyl CoA.
Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 146.

questions.text: What are the cut-off values for an oral glucose tolerance test performed after fasting and one and two hours after eating?
questions.solution:
Cut-off values in 2 hours oral glucose tolerance test for fasting and at 1 hour and 2 hours after meals are 92, 180 and 153  respectively.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 3768.

questions.text: Which of the following does not function as a cofactor for glycogen phosphorylase, a crucial enzyme in the glycogenolysis pathway?
questions.solution:
An enzyme called glycogenin helps turn glucose into glycogen. By polymerizing the initial few glucose molecules, it serves as a primer before other enzymes take over. As a result, it participates in glycogen synthesis rather than glycogenolysis.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 173.

choices.text: The thermodynamics does not favor such a reaction to occur
Glucose-6-phosphatase is present in the endoplasmic reticulum and cannot act on glycogen formed in the cytoplasm
Glycogenesis and glycogenolysis are tightly regulated such that enzymes of only one of those is present at a time

questions.text: Glycogen synthesis and breakdown occur in the same cell, which contains the enzymes required for both pathways. Why is it that freshly generated glucose-6-phosphate in the cytoplasm of hepatocytes is not instantly degraded by the enzyme glucose6-phosphatase?
questions.solution:
Hepatocytes produce glucose-6-phosphate in their cytoplasm, and their endoplasmic reticulum contains the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase. As a result, the reaction doesn't happen until gluconeogenesis is encouraged.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 174.

questions.text: Which of these substrates is not glucogenic?
questions.solution:
Acetyl-CoA is unable to enter the gluconeogenic pathway. This is because Pyruvate Dehydrogenase enzyme is not bidirectional it's a committed step.
Substrates that can undergo gluconeogenesis are:
1.lactate
2.gluconeogenic amino acids
3.glycerol
4.pyruvate
5.fumarate
Audio for the above.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 142.

questions.text: Fasting-state gluconeogenesis is suggested by:
questions.solution:
Option A- Activation of acetyl co-A by citrate is a key step of fatty acid synthesis which occurs in well fed state. 

Option B- Activation and not inactivation of pyruvate carboxylase by acetyl co-A to generate oxaloacetate is the first step of gluconeogenesis pathway. 

Option D- Fructose 2,6 bisphosphate is an allosteric activator of PFK1 which catalyzes the rate limiting enzyme of glycolysis in well fed state. 

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 145.

questions.text: Which of the following is a quick source of energy for working out muscles by resynthesizing ATP?
questions.solution:
Rapid source of energy by resynthesizing ATP for exercising muscles is Phosphorylcreatine.

At the junction of the myosin heads and actin, phosphorylcreatine is hydrolyzed during exercise, generating ATP from ADP and allowing contraction to continue.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 112.

questions.text: A patient exhibits a positive Benedicts test in urine and has normal blood glucose levels as determined by the glucose-oxidase peroxidase technique. What of the following is most likely to be the cause?
questions.solution:
The answer to this questions stands Galactosemia

While the glucose oxidase strip test is specific for Glucose, Benedict's test is positive for all reducing sugars, including Glucose, galactose, and fructose.

Since, There's nothing like fructosemia (water soluble excreted in urine) only viable option remaining is Galactosemia.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 200.

questions.text: Select the option that is most effective for gluconeogenesis in starvation.
questions.solution:
“In gluconeogenesis, pyruvate carboxylase, which catalyzes the synthesis of oxaloacetate from pyruvate, requires acetylCoA as an allosteric activator. The presence of acetyl-CoA results in a change in the tertiary structure of the protein, lowering the Km value for bicarbonate. This means that as acetyl-CoA is formed from pyruvate, it automatically ensures the provision of oxaloacetate and, therefore, its further oxidation in the citric acid cycle. The activation of pyruvate carboxylase and the reciprocal inhibition of pyruvate dehydrogenase by acetyl-CoA derived from the oxidation of fatty acids explains the action of fatty acid oxidation in sparing the oxidation of pyruvate and in stimulating gluconeogenesis. The reciprocal relationship between these two enzymes in both liver and kidney alters the metabolic fate of pyruvate as the tissue changes from carbohydrate oxidation, via glycolysis, to gluconeogenesis during transition from a fed to a fasting state.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 184.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an intermediate product of the citric acid cycle?4.
questions.solution:
Acetyl-CoA is the initial molecule of the citric acid cycle, while Succinyl-CoA, a-Ketoglutarate and Citrate are the intermediates within the cycle. Thus, Acetyl-CoA is not part of the intermediates, but rather the beginning compound of the citric acid cycle.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 157.

questions.text: Which enzyme is common to both glycogenolysis and glycogenesis?
questions.solution:
Glucose-6-phosphatase is the common enzyme for both glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis pathways, it is present in the liver and kidney, absent in muscle and adipose tissue, that catalyses the breakdown of glucose-6-phosphate into glucose. This breakdown leads to an increase in the concentration of glucose in the blood. Lack of this enzyme results in glycogen storage disease type I, which causes a build-up of glycogen in the liver and renal cells, hypoglycemia, lactic acidemia, ketosis and hyperlipidemia.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 173.

questions.text: In an electron transport system, which part will be the last to get electrons?
questions.solution:
The electron transport chain necessitates oxygen, so this chain is also known as the respiratory chain since it is responsible for the most significant use of oxygen in the body. In this chain, electrons come together with oxygen and protons to produce water.



Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 119.

questions.text: Pick the option that is not glucogenic.
questions.solution:
Acetyl CoA cannot enter the glucogenic pathway.

Glucogenic amino acids (all except Leucine and lysine which are purely ketogenic) — Most important =Alanine

Lactate

Glycerol

Oxaloacetate is reduced to malate using NADH, a step required for its transportation out of the mitochondria. Malate is oxidized to oxaloacetate using NAD+ in the cytosol, where the remaining steps of gluconeogenesis take place.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 180.

questions.text: Which one of these amino acids does not enter the Krebs cycle by forming Acetyl CoA via pyruvate?
questions.solution:
Amino acids enter the Krebs cycle through various pathways, and some do so by being converted into pyruvate, which is then transformed into Acetyl CoA. Here's how these amino acids are metabolized:

  1. Glycine:

    • Glycine can convert into serine, which is then metabolized to pyruvate.
    • Enters the Krebs cycle via pyruvate → Acetyl CoA.

  2. Tyrosine:

    • Tyrosine is broken down into fumarate and acetoacetate. These products enter the Krebs cycle but not through pyruvate or Acetyl CoA.
    • Does not use the pyruvate pathway.

  3. Hydroxyproline:

    • Hydroxyproline is derived from proline and can be converted into pyruvate.
    • Enters via pyruvate → Acetyl CoA.

  4. Alanine:

    • Alanine is transaminated directly to pyruvate.
    • Enters via pyruvate → Acetyl CoA.



Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 160.

questions.text: A toddler who accidentally ingested cyanide is sent to the hospital. It prevents the citric acid cycle by preventing:
questions.solution:
Cyanide blocks Complex IV (Cytochrome oxidase) of Electron transport Chain. It has no direct effect on any component of Citric acid cycle. If the electron transport chain is blocked, then the electron carriers NADH and FADH cannot unload their electrons into it, which means NAD+ and FAD are not regenerated. Since Glycolysis and the Krebs cycle both require NAD+ (and the Krebs cycle requires FAD), NAD+ will get depleted and NADH level is raised, both of these processes will stop running.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 116.

questions.text: Which of the following is not responsible for ketosis in a patient with Von Gierke disease?
questions.solution:
Option 4, "Low fat mobilization", is the correct answer because it is not responsible for ketosis in a patient with Von Gierke disease.

In fact, individuals with Von Gierke disease have an increased tendency to accumulate fat in their liver, which can lead to further complications.
Therefore, options 1, 2, and 3 are incorrect because they are all associated with hypoglycemia, which is a primary feature of Von Gierke disease and can lead to ketosis.
Option 4 is the correct answer because low fat mobilization is not a contributing factor to ketosis in individuals with Von Gierke disease.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 174.

questions.text: Which enzyme's activity increases when insulin /glucagon  level are low?
questions.solution:
Insulin suppresses glucose-6-phosphatase gene. Glucose-6-phosphatase activity is increased in low insulin/glucagon level.

In these kind of questions - High I/G ratio means fed state vs Low I/G ratio points towards fasting. Now think what body does then - Here’s a concise table showing which processes occur during the fed and fasting states:
Process Fed State Fasting State
Glycogenesis Active (liver, muscle) Inactive
Glycogenolysis Inactive Active (liver, muscle)
Glycolysis Active Inactive
Gluconeogenesis Inactive Active (liver, kidney)
Lipogenesis Active (liver, adipose) Inactive
Lipolysis Inactive Active (adipose tissue)
Ketogenesis Inactive Active (liver)
Proteolysis Inactive Active (muscle)

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 188.

choices.text: Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency causes decreased synthesis of NADPH

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding NADPH is false?
questions.solution:
NADPH does not produce ATP in RBCs as RBC lacks mitochondria. 

NADPH is required for:

 
  • As a co-enzyme, it performs reductive biosynthesis of all lipids, including fatty acid synthesis, cholesterol synthesis, and bile acid synthesis. 
  • Regenerating depleted glutathione in RBCs and stabilising or protecting the membrane from oxidative stress.
Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 193.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presented to pediatric OPD with hepatospleenomegaly. Large cells that resemble crumpled paper were seen on bone marrow examination. In these cells, which of the following must have accumulated?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of Gaucher's disease, caused by the deposition of Glucocerebrosides due to deficiency of beta- glucocerebrosidase. 

The cerebrocide-laden cells are large and have eccentric nuclei.

The cytoplasm appears like crumpled silk or tissue paper (Gaucher's Cells).

With the electron microscope, the fibrillary cytoplasm can be resolved as elongated, distended lysosomes containing the stored lipid in stacks of bilayers.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 245.

questions.text: Pick the enzyme that catalyses the irreversible steps of glycolysis?
questions.solution:
Reactions catalyzed by hexokinase (glucokinase), phosphofructokinase, and pyruvate kinase, are the three major sites of regulation of glycolysis as other reactions of glycolysis are reversible.

The reactions catalyzed by these three enzymes are markedly exergonic and are considered to be physiologically irreversible.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 165.

choices.text: Oxaloacetate, required for gluconeogenesis, is present in excess.

questions.text: Ketosis was discovered after an examination of a patient who had Von gierke disease. Which of the following is not correct regarding the described condition?
questions.solution:
Von Gierke's disease is a type 1 glycogen storage disorder which occurs due to deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatse.

Due to deficiency of this enzyme, liver is unable to release glucose into bloodstream during fasting. Therefore, in order to produce glucose, body shifts to gluconeogenesis but fails again due to deficiency of the enzyme.

Excess glucose-6-phosphate, therefore, enters HMP pathway to form purines and this in turn results in hyperuricemia.

Glucose-6-phopshate is broken down to acetyl co-A for utilization in TCA cycle but this process does not occur due to depletion of oxaloacetate( OAA decreases and no rise as it gets diverted to gluconeogenesis). It is therefore, diverted towards fatty acid and ketone body synthesis causing hypertriglyceridemia and ketosis.

OAA is in excess for gluconeogenesis but not for ketosis.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 174.

questions.text: A three month old newborn, who was healthy at birth develops chronic liver failure and muscle weakness. On examinations, serum glucose is low, associated with ketoacidosis and reduced pH. The ALT and AST levels rise. Uric acid and lactate levels in the blood are normal. When administered intravenously, glucagon elevates blood sugar levels after meals but not after an overnight fast. Liver biopsy shows increased glycogen in liver. Which enzyme in this youngster is most likely to be defective?
questions.solution:
In this child, a combination of liver and muscle involvement with ketoacidosis and raised liver enzymes in a setting of Hypoglycemia especially in fasting state, points towards Type III Glycogen Storage disease, i.e. Cori's disease caused by deficiency of Debranching enzyme. The liver Biopsy confirms diagnosis. The muscle weakness due to any other cause is ruled out by normal urate and lactate.
Type Name Deficient Enzyme Key Specific Features
Type I Von Gierke Disease Glucose-6-phosphatase Severe fasting hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, lactic acidosis
Type II Pompe Disease Lysosomal acid α-glucosidase Cardiomegaly, muscle weakness, "floppy baby" (infantile form)
Type III Cori Disease Debranching enzyme (α-1,6-glucosidase) Milder hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, accumulation of limit dextrin
Type IV Andersen Disease Branching enzyme Hepatosplenomegaly, liver cirrhosis, early death
Type V McArdle Disease Muscle glycogen phosphorylase Exercise intolerance, muscle cramps, myoglobinuria (red urine)
Type VI Hers Disease Liver glycogen phosphorylase Mild fasting hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 174.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes has decreased activity when you're fasting?
questions.solution:
• The correct answer is: 3. Acetyl Co-A carboxylase.
  • The enzyme that has decreased activity when fasting is acetyl Co-A carboxylase.
  • Acetyl Co-A carboxylase is a key enzyme in fatty acid synthesis and is inhibited by glucagon during fasting to prevent energy storage.
Other options
  • Hormone-sensitive lipase has increased activity as it is activated by glucagon and epinephrine, leading to triglyceride breakdown.
  • Glycogen phosphorylase also has increased activity as it promotes glycogen breakdown to maintain blood glucose levels.
  • Glucose-6-phosphatase has increased activity as it helps in gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis, releasing glucose into the bloodstream.
Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no166.

questions.text: A male adolescent patient complained of calf soreness during activity. A biopsy revealed that the muscle had an abnormal amount of glycogen. What type of enzyme deficit is most likely?
questions.solution:
Type V Glycogen Storage Disease (Muscle Phosphorylase Deficiency, McArdle Disease): GSD V is caused by the deficiency of muscle phosphorylase activity. Lack of this enzyme limits muscle ATP generation by glycogenolysis, resulting in muscle glycogen accumulation, and is the prototype of muscle energy disorders. Deficiency of myophosphorylase impairs the cleavage of glucosyl molecules from the straight chain of glycogen.

Symptoms are generally characterized by exercise intolerance with muscle cramps and pain. Two types of activity tend to cause symptoms: brief exercise of great intensity, such as sprinting or carrying heavy loads; and less intense but sustained activity, such as climbing stairs or walking uphill.

 

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 174.

questions.text: Which metabolic process is inhibited by fluoride produced from fluoroacetate?
Which is the best method to measure HbA1c?
questions.solution:
The four most commonly used methods for determining HbAlc levels are immunoassay, ion-exchange high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC), boronate affinity HPLC, and enzymatic assays. Immunoassays typically measure HbAlc specifically, as antibodies detect the structure of the N-terminal glycated amino acids (which typically consist of the first 4-10 amino acids) of the Hb B chain. On the other hand, ion-exchange HPLC separates Hb species based on the contrast in charge between HbA1c and the other hemoglobins. Thus, Best method is ion exchange chromatography.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 25.

questions.text: Which enzyme deficit leads to galactosemia?
questions.solution:
Galactose converts to Galactose 1 phosphate with the help of Galactokinase. Its deficiency causes increase in Galactitol( oil drop cataract). Galactose 1 Phosphate coverts to Glucose1 phosphate with the help of Uridyltransferase. Its deficiency causes Galactosemia.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 200.

choices.text: Absence of Digestive enzyme in the upper GIT

questions.text: Because fructan are not digested, they are employed as prebiotics just as inulin. Their resistance to digestion in upper GI tract is because of:
questions.solution:
Fructans are polysaccharides composed of fructose units, which can be linked together by β(2→1) or β(2→6) glycosidic bonds. The β-configuration refers to the orientation of the glycosidic bond relative to the plane of the sugar ring. In the β-configuration, the hydroxyl group attached to the anomeric carbon (C2 in fructose) is on the opposite side (axial position) of the ring relative to the CH2OH group at C6.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 152.

questions.text: A young patient arrives with hypoglycemia and hepatomegaly. Even after epinephrine injection, blood sugar levels do not improve. What plausible diagnosis is there?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Von Gierke's disease Von Gierke’s disease is characterized by absence of glucose-6-phosphate. Normally, administration of intravenous epinephrine results in glycogenolysis via stimulation of glucose-6-phosphatase which is the rate limiting enzyme of the metabolic pathway. This is known as IV epinephrine challenge test. However, in Von Gierke’s disease, this phenomenon does not occur in well fed state as well as fasting state owing to deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase. IV epinephrine challenge test is primarily used to differentiate Von Gierke’s disease from Cori’s In Cori’s disease which occurs due to deficiency of debranching enzyme, some amount of glucose synthesis occurs via breakdown of glycogen by glycogen phosphorylase. This combined with dietary glucose leads to surge in blood glucose levels in well-fed state. However, during overnight fasting, this does not occur due to ineffective glycogenolysis.
Type Name Deficient Enzyme Key Specific Features
Type I Von Gierke Disease Glucose-6-phosphatase Severe fasting hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, lactic acidosis
Type II Pompe Disease Lysosomal acid α-glucosidase Cardiomegaly, muscle weakness, "floppy baby" (infantile form)
Type III Cori Disease Debranching enzyme (α-1,6-glucosidase) Milder hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, accumulation of limit dextrin
Type IV Andersen Disease Branching enzyme Hepatosplenomegaly, liver cirrhosis, early death
Type V McArdle Disease Muscle glycogen phosphorylase Exercise intolerance, muscle cramps, myoglobinuria (red urine)
Type VI Hers Disease Liver glycogen phosphorylase Mild fasting hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 174.

questions.text: In a fasting condition, which of the following is utilised by RBC?
questions.solution:
The brain and red blood cells require glucose during fasting and starvation; in the early stages of fasting, this is given by glycogen stores.
When insulin secretion is low, muscle and other tissues don't absorb glucose to conserve it; instead, they choose to use fatty acids (and eventually ketone bodies) as fuel.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 146.

questions.text:
Which of the following enzyme marker combinations is/are correct for disorders?
i. Beta glucocerebrosidase - Von Gierke’s disease
ii. Lipase - Acute pancreatitis
iii.Ceruloplasmin-Hepatolenticular degenration
iv. LDH 1:LDH 2 Ratio - Myocardial infarction
questions.solution:
Triglycerides are hydrolyzed by lipase into beta-monoglycerides and fatty acids. The pancreatic secretion contains the enzyme. In acute pancreatitis, the amount in the blood is significantly raised.
ferroxidase, a.k.a. ceruloplasmin. It increases in all inflammatory conditions, collagen disorders, cancers, and pregnancy since it is an acute phase protein.
Pyruvate will be converted to lactate by the LDH. Total LDH activity is raised in myocardial infarction, while H4 iso-enzyme activity is increased 5–10 times greater. Normal blood LDH-2 (H3M1) concentrations are higher than LDH-1 (H4) concentrations; however, this pattern is flipped in myocardial infarction, and this is known as the flipped pattern.
Deﬁciency of glucose-6-phosphatase occurs in von Gierkie's disease. As glucose-6-phosphate builds up, it is diverted to the HMP shunt pathway, where it produces more ribose and purine nucleotides. The conversion of purines to uric acid follows leading to hyperuricemia.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 174.

questions.text: Which among the following options given below have maximum water absorption ?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, pectin has the maximum water absorption capacity.

Explanation:

• Pectin: A highly hydrophilic polysaccharide that forms gels by binding large amounts of water. It has the greatest water-holding capacity among the options.

• Mucilage: Also absorbs water well but generally not as much as pectin.

• Hemicellulose: Can retain some water but is less hydrophilic than pectin.

• Lignin: Has minimal water absorption as it is a highly hydrophobic and rigid polymer.

.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 154.

questions.text: Mention the enzyme which gets activated when there is decrease in insulin: glucagon ratio:
questions.solution:
• Insulin and glucagon are both hormones responsible for maintaining glucose (sugar) levels in the blood.
  • Their ratio helps regulate the activity of several enzymes, which are proteins that speed up chemical reactions in the body.
  • An increase in the insulin-to-glucagon ratio reduces the activity of hormone-sensitive lipase, an enzyme responsible for breaking down fat stored in the body. In contrast, an increase in the glucagon-to-insulin ratio activates the enzyme, increasing the breakdown of stored fat.
The ratio also regulates enzymes involved in the synthesis of fatty acids, the breakdown of glycogen, and the breakdown and synthesis of glucose in the liver by there action on Glucose 6 phosphatase. In this way, the insulin-to-glucagon ratio controls many of the metabolic pathways within the body.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 144.

questions.text:
Which of the following enzymes is involved in the production of glucose?
A. Pyruvate carboxylase
B. Phosphoenolpyruvate kinase
C. Hexokinase
D. Pyruvate kinase
E. Glucose 6 phosphatase
questions.solution:
• The first step in gluconeogenesis is the conversion of pyruvate to phosphoenolpyruvic acid (PEP). In order to convert pyruvate to PEP there are several steps and several enzymes required.
  • Pyruvate carboxylase, PEP carboxykinase and malate dehydrogenase are the three enzymes responsible for this conversion in gluconeogenesis.
  • Glucose -6- phosphatase converts glucose 6-phosphate to glucose.

questions.text: Which of the following substances does not produce glucose?
questions.solution:
Acetyl CoA is purely ketogenic because Pyruvate Dehydrogenase enzyme is irreversible and acetyl CoA thus cannot form Pyruvate. Pyruvate is both glucogenic and ketogenic. Oxaloacetate, Citrate, Succinylcholine CoA, Fumarate are glucogenic.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 171.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency is true?
i. Decrease in NADPH
ii. Decrease in reduced glutathione
iii. Decrease in lipid peroxidation
iv. Decreased RBC membrane damage
questions.solution:
• G6PD catalyses the transformation of glucose 6-phosphate into 6-phosphogluconic acid.
  • NADPH is produced in this process, keeping GSH in its reduced, active state.

questions.text:
In a student-run experiment on ETC, the addition of pyruvate and one inhibitor prevented oxidative phosphorylation from occurring.
Which inhibitor did the student most likely use?
questions.solution:
Oligomycin completely blocks oxidation and phosphorylation by blocking the flow of protons through ATP synthase.
 

Here’s a table showing the Electron Transport Chain (ETC) complexes and their blockers:

Step/Complex Enzyme/Function Blockers Effect
Complex I NADH: Ubiquinone Oxidoreductase Rotenone, Amytal, Piericidin A Inhibits electron transfer from NADH to CoQ
Complex II Succinate Dehydrogenase Malonate (competitive inhibitor) Blocks FADH₂ oxidation, reducing CoQ flow
Complex III Cytochrome bc₁ Complex Antimycin A Blocks transfer of electrons to Cytochrome c
Complex IV Cytochrome c Oxidase Cyanide, Carbon monoxide (CO), Azide Prevents transfer of electrons to oxygen
ATP Synthase (Complex V) F₀F₁ ATP Synthase Oligomycin Inhibits ATP production
Uncouplers Disrupt proton gradient DNP, FCCP, Thermogenin ATP synthesis stops, but O₂ consumption increases

questions.text: A 22-year-old male who had diarrhoea and a dairy intolerance was seen. He was later diagnosed with lactase deficiency. Which of the following agents is least likely to result in lactose intolerance?

questions.text: Gluconeogenesis and glycolysis share which enzyme:
questions.solution:
Enzyme present in both glycolysis and gluconeogenesis is phosphoglycerate kinase.

Phosphoglycerate kinase or PGK is a major enzyme used in glycolysis, in the first ATP-generating step of the glycolytic pathway.
In gluconeogenesis, the reaction catalysed by PGK proceeds in the opposite direction, generating ADP and 1,3-BPG.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 182.

questions.solution:
Glucose is stored in Glycogen form because it is compact.

Because glycogen is so heavily branched, it is able to pack more glucose units together in a small space, thus it is more compact and has a greater solubility.

questions.text: What determines the rate of gluconeogenesis during extended starvation?
questions.solution:
During prolonged starvation, the rate of gluconeogenesis depends upon increased alanine levels in liver. Alanine is synthesized and secreted from the skeletal muscle that is used as substrates of gluconeogenesis in the liver. Alanine is exported to the liver where it is transaminated to pyruvate, which serves as a substrate for gluconeogenesis.
