choices.text: To trap the glucose in the cell
To prevent it to be used for glycogen synthesis

questions.text: What does the first phase of glycolysis, which turns glucose into glucose-6-phosphate, help with?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: To trap the glucose in the cell

The first step of glycolysis is to convert glucose into glucose-6-phosphate with the help of enzyme hexokinase/glucokinase.
This step traps the glucose intracellularly so that it can be utilized in various metabolic pathways or else glucose will diffuse back into the bloodstream because there is no transporter for glucose-6-phosphate present. 

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 113.

choices.text: Stimulation of ETC to generate heat & energy
Inhibition of ATP formation by inhibiting phosphorylation of ADP

questions.text: What is the effect of thyroxine hormone on a electron transport chain?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Inhibition of ATP formation by inhibiting phosphorylation of ADP
  • Thyroxine hormone is produced by the thyroid gland and is involved in the regulation of metabolism. It affects various processes in the body, including the electron transport chain (ETC), which is responsible for the production of ATP (adenosine triphosphate) - the energy currency of the cell.
  • Option 1 is incorrect because although thyroxine hormone does stimulate the ETC, it does not specifically stimulate it to generate heat and energy. The ETC is always involved in the production of ATP, which is a form of energy.
  • Option 2 is incorrect because thyroxine hormone does not inhibit the ETC by inhibiting complex 1. In fact, thyroxine hormone increases the activity of the ETC by increasing the activity of complex IV.
  • Option 3 is correct because thyroxine hormone inhibits ATP formation by inhibiting the phosphorylation of ADP. This means that although the ETC may still be active, the production of ATP is reduced because ADP is not being converted to ATP. Thyroxine is a physiological uncoupler.
  • Option 4 is incorrect because as mentioned earlier, thyroxine hormone does affect the ETC by increasing its activity through complex IV.
  • In summary, the correct option is 3 because thyroxine hormone inhibits ATP formation by inhibiting the phosphorylation of ADP.
Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 128.

questions.text: Which category of carbohydrates does fructose belong to?
questions.solution:
Correct option 1:Ketose monosaccharide

Fructose is a ketose monosaccharide, meaning it contains a ketone functional group (C=O) within its structure. 

  1. Chemical Structure: Fructose has the molecular formula C6H12O6 and the same empirical formula (CH2O)n as glucose and other monosaccharides. However, its structure differs in the positioning of the carbonyl group.

  2. Ketose vs. Aldose: Monosaccharides are classified based on the position of their carbonyl group (either an aldehyde or a ketone group). In fructose, the carbonyl group is a ketone, located on the second carbon atom of the molecule.

  3. Sweetness: Fructose is notably sweeter than glucose, which is one reason why it's commonly used as a sweetener in various foods and beverages.

  4. Sources: It naturally occurs in fruits (hence its name, which is derived from Latin "fructus" meaning fruit) and is also found in honey and some vegetables.

Metabolism: Fructose is metabolized differently than glucose. It is primarily metabolized in the liver, where it can be converted into glucose or stored as glycogen.

​​​​​​​Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 536.148

questions.text: Which statement is true about the structure of Glycogen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Is a homopolysaccharide of glucose
 
  • Glycogen is a branched polymer of alpha D glucose with alpha 1-4 glycosidic bond in linear chain and alpha 1-6 glycosidic bond at branching points.
  • Stored in the cytoplasm of cell in the form of alpha rosettes.
  • Predominant storage form of carbohydrate in the body due to-
  • Compact nature
  • Large number of non-reducing ends which facilitates faster release of glucose during glycolysis
  • Low molarity of glycogen which does not lead to cellular swelling.
Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 153.

questions.text: Cori cycle is important for transporting:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Lactate from muscle to liver

Cori’s cycle is also known as glucose lactate cycle.
Involves transport of lactate from muscle to liver in order to prevent lactic acidosis inside muscle as well as for utilization of lactate as a substrate for gluconeogenesis.



Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 186.

questions.text: For the production of__________, the pentose phosphate pathway is important.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Both 2 and 3

Pentose phosphate pathway/phosphogluconate pathway/Dickens Horecker pathway serves as an important pathway for the generation of NAPDH and ribose precursors.
Important functions of NADPH-
  • Free radicle scavenger.
  • Synthesis of fatty acids and steroid hormones.
  • Keeps iron in reduced state in hemoglobin (Fe2+) in order to prevent methemoglobinemia.
Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 193.

questions.text: Which of the following metabolic processes doesn't result in ATP production?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4:  HMP Pathway 
  • Pentose phosphate pathway/phosphogluconate pathway/Dickens Horecker pathway serves as an important pathway for the generation of NAPDH and ribose precursors.
  • It takes place in cytoplasm of the cell.
  • Does not result in production of ATP.
Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 193.

questions.text: What is the Warburg effect?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Aerobic glycolysis
The Warburg Effect refers to the phenomenon where cancer cells preferentially use glycolysis for energy production even in the presence of oxygen (aerobic conditions). Hence, this is called as aerobic glycolysis. (versus when cell normally uses glycolysis for ATP in absence of oxygen i.e anaerobic conditions)

Key Features of Warburg Effect
  • Cancer cells rely on glycolysis → Convert glucose to lactate, even when oxygen is available.
  • Less ATP per glucose molecule (compared to oxidative phosphorylation), but faster ATP production.
  • Increased glucose uptake (basis for PET scans using FDG in cancer detection)
Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 704.

questions.text: Which of the following doesn't occur when the liver's glucose content drops?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Increased levels of Fructose 2, 6-Bisphosphate

Fructose 2,6 bisphosphate is an allosteric activator of phosphofructokinase 1 which is the rate limiting enzyme of glycolysis.
When the glucose content of liver drops, there is increase in glucagon/insulin ratio which inhibits glycolysis by activating fructose 2,6 bisphosphatase which breaks down fructose 2,6 bisphosphate as well as by inhibiting phosphofructokinase 2 which prevents its further synthesis, thereby preventing glycolysis to take place.


Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 165.

questions.text: When compared to fasting for 12 to 24 hours, all of the following metabolic changes occur during prolonged fasting, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
The correct answer is: 2. Liver gluconeogenesis increases

During prolonged fasting (beyond 24 hours to several days), the body shifts its metabolic strategy to conserve protein and rely more on fat-derived energy sources, particularly ketone bodies. Let's review each option:

  1. Brain use of ketone bodies increases – True. After 2-3 days of fasting, the brain starts using ketone bodies (produced from fatty acids) as an alternative energy source to reduce dependence on glucose.

  2. Liver gluconeogenesis increases – False. Liver gluconeogenesis actually decreases during prolonged fasting because the body prioritizes protein conservation. Initially (12-24 hours), gluconeogenesis is high to maintain blood glucose levels, but as fasting continues, ketone bodies take over as the primary energy source, reducing the need for glucose production.

  3. Muscle protein degradation decreases – True. As ketone bodies become the main energy source, muscle breakdown (which provides amino acids for gluconeogenesis) decreases to preserve muscle mass.

  4. Brain use of glucose decreases – True. As ketone body utilization increases, the brain reduces its dependence on glucose to minimize muscle protein breakdown.

    Hence, the option (2) is a false statement. 
     

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 144.

questions.text: After 12–24 hours of not eating, which of the following metabolic activities won't take place?
questions.solution:
During fasting for 12-24 hours glycogen would be slowly depleted, ketone bodies formation and free fatty acids will increase. But in just 24 hours of fasting serum proteins won't decrease. Serum protein might decrease in cases of chronic malnutrition. Thus, decrease in serum proteins is the answer.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 196.

questions.text: There are Alder-Reilley bodies seen in which condition:
questions.solution:
The correct option is 1: Mucopolysaccharidosis

Alder Reilly bodies are coarse granules seen in cytoplasm of white blood cells such as neutrophils, monocytes, and lymphocytes in mucopolysaccharidosis.

Other options:-
  • Langerhans cell histiocytosis Birbeck granules is seen.
  • Chediak-Higashi syndrome coarse granules is seen in leukocytes in PBS. 



Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 163.

questions.text: What is the net number of molecules of ATP gained from one glucose in aerobic glycolysis when the G3P Shuttle is utilized?
questions.solution:
• The net number of molecules of ATP gained from one glucose in aerobic glycolysis when the G3P shuttle is utilized is 6.
  • During glycolysis, glucose is broken down into two molecules of pyruvate.
  • In the presence of oxygen, pyruvate enters the mitochondria and is converted to acetyl-CoA, which then enters the citric acid cycle.
  • The citric acid cycle generates NADH and FADH2, which donate electrons to the electron transport chain (ETC) to generate ATP through oxidative phosphorylation.
  • However, in the absence of oxygen, pyruvate is converted to lactate or ethanol, and the NADH generated during glycolysis is oxidized back to NAD+ by reducing pyruvate or acetaldehyde to lactate or ethanol.
  • his process is called fermentation. The G3P shuttle is an alternative pathway for the transport of electrons from cytosolic NADH into the mitochondria. In this pathway, cytosolic NADH reduces dihydroxyacetone phosphate (DHAP) to form glycerol-3-phosphate (G3P), which can enter the mitochondria and donate electrons to the ETC through FADH2.
  • This pathway generates 2 molecules of ATP per cytosolic NADH, compared to 3 molecules of ATP per mitochondrial NADH.
  • Therefore, in the presence of oxygen and the utilization of the G3P shuttle, the net number of molecules of ATP gained from one glucose in aerobic glycolysis is 6 (2 from glycolysis, 2 from the citric acid cycle, and 2 from the G3P shuttle).
Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 104.

questions.text: Which of the following is a complex-IV inhibitor:
questions.solution:
Cyanide is an inhibitor of cytochrome complex IV. 

Trick- Inhibitors of complex IV end with -IDE Eg- hydrogen sulfide, carbon monoxide, cyanide, sodium azide. 

Option A- CO2 is an end product of oxidative phosphorylation.

Option C-Oligomycin blocks the flow of protons, thus inhibiting synthesis of ATP. 

Option D- Malonate is an inhibitor of complex II



Reference: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st edition, Page no 123, 145, 472.

questions.text: A Mediterranean person was taking primaquine and he developed hemolytic anemia. It was found that he was having G-6-PD deficiency. Which of the pathway is associated with this clinical syndrome?
questions.solution:
Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase is an enzyme of HMP pathway.  It's primary role is to generate NADPH which is essential to form reduced glutathione. 

The reduced glutathione is essential to maintain integrity of erythrocytes against oxidative stress.


Reference: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st edition, Page no 157, 172, 175, 182.
Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 782, 784.

questions.text: Glycogen phosphorylase is activated directly/indirectly by
questions.solution:
Factors activating glycogen phosphorylase are:
  • cAMP
  • Glucagon
  • epinephrine
  • Norepinephrine
  • Ca+2


Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st edition, Page no 167, 168.

questions.text: The significance of HMP shunt are all except?
questions.solution:
The hexose monophosphate (HMP) shunt, also known as the pentose phosphate pathway (PPP), is a metabolic pathway that occurs in the cytoplasm and serves several important functions. However, it does not generate ATP.

The hexose monophosphate (HMP) shunt, also known as the pentose phosphate pathway, is crucial for several reasons and has the following functions:

  1. NADPH Production: The pathway generates NADPH, which is essential for anabolic reactions, including fatty acid and cholesterol synthesis, and for maintaining the reduced state of glutathione in cells.
  2. Ribose-5-Phosphate Generation: It produces ribose-5-phosphate, 5 carbon sugar -a precursor for nucleotide and nucleic acid synthesis, which is vital for cell division and growth.
  3. Antioxidant Defense: NADPH produced by the HMP shunt helps regenerate reduced glutathione, a key antioxidant that protects cells from oxidative stress.
Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 146.

questions.text: A child presents with complaints of lethargy and weakness in between meals. The symptoms disappeared on feeding. No glycogen was present in the liver. Which of these enzymes could be deficient in the child?
questions.solution:
The symptoms of lethargy and weakness that disappear on feeding are suggestive of hypoglycemia. The vignette further mentions liver examination findings revealing No glycogen suggesting a deficiency in glycogen synthesis.

Glycogen synthase is the enzyme responsible for catalyzing the transfer of glucose from UDP-glucose to the nonreducing ends of glycogen chains, leading to the synthesis of glycogen.

 

Deficiency of this enzyme leads to an inability to synthesize glycogen (rate-limiting step of glycogenesis), which results in hypoglycemia between meals. The symptoms disappear in the fed state because glucose obtained from the meal maintains blood glucose levels.

Reference: Harpar’s illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition, Page. No- 178.

questions.text: An adolescent boy has muscle cramps and low lactate after exercise. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has McArdle disease (glycogen storage disease type V). 
  • This condition is caused by a deficiency of myophosphorylase, an isoenzyme of glycogen phosphorylase present in muscle tissue.
  • Deficiency leads to decreased breakdown of glycogen during exercise, resulting in poor exercise tolerance, muscle cramps, and rhabdomyolysis (eg, red urine), as occurred in this patient.
  • Approximately 50% of patients report burgundy-colored urine after exercise, which is the consequence of exercise-induced myoglobinuria secondary to rhabdomyolysis. Intense myoglobinuria after vigorous exercise may cause acute renal failure. In rare cases, electromyographic findings may suggest an inflammatory myopathy and the diagnosis can be confused with polymyositis.
     

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 20th Edition, Page. No- 724.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in patients with Hyperinsulinemia?
questions.solution:
Insulin increases fatty acid synthesis in adipose tissues.

* Functions of Insulin:
  1. Insulin maintains blood glucose at a constant level within the defined normal range.
  2. Insulin facilitates the movement of glucose from the bloodstream into the cell.
  3. Insulin is the anabolic hormone that stimulates glucose uptake into the fat and muscles.
  4. Insulin promotes the conversion of glucose into glycogen or fat storage.
  5. Insulin inhibits glucose production from the liver.
  6. Insulin stimulates protein synthesis and inhibits protein breakdown.
Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page. No- 426.

questions.text: Glycogen Phosphorylase enzymes require which of the following for its activation?
questions.solution:
Glycogen Phosphorylase requires Calcium to attain its fully activated state- Its phosphorylated form.



Reference: Harpar’s illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page. No: 176, 178.

questions.text: Insulin independent glucose transporter is present in all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Insulin dependent Glucose transporter is found in Adipose tissues. GLUT 4 receptor is found in Cardiac, skeletal and Adipose tissue which causes insulin dependent glucose uptake in tissues.

Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page. No- 426, 427.

questions.text: Which of the following two monosaccharides are constituents of lactulose?
questions.solution:
Lactulose is a synthetic disaccharide used primarily as a laxative and in the management of hepatic encephalopathy.

Key points:

  • It is composed of galactose and fructose linked by a β-1,4-glycosidic bond.

  • Mechanism in hepatic encephalopathy:

    • Fermented by gut bacteria → produces lactic acid and acetic acid, lowering colonic pH.

    • Acidic environment traps ammonia as ammonium ions, reducing absorption into the bloodstream.

  • Other sugar pairs:

    • Galactose + glucose → lactose

    • Glucose + fructose → sucrose

    • Fructose + mannose → not commonly found in therapeutic disaccharides

questions.text: In Pompe‘s disease, the enzyme deficient is?
questions.solution:
Pompe‘s disease results from a deficiency in the enzyme lysosomal alpha-glucosidase

Pompe‘s disease, also known as Type II glycogen storage disorder, is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme acid maltase or lysosomal acid alpha-glucosidase. This disorder is rapidly progressive, leading to symptoms such as hypotonia and hepatosplenomegaly. The involvement of the heart muscle (myocardium) distinguishes Pompe‘s disease from other glycogen storage disorders.

Hepatomegaly in Pompe‘s disease is due to the accumulation of glycogen in ballooned lysosomes, which gives the cells a characteristic lacy cytoplasmic appearance. Cardiac and skeletal muscles exhibit enlargement and contain clear spaces filled with glycogen in the lysosomes. While this condition typically has a poor prognosis, recent advancements in enzyme replacement therapy have improved survival rates.

 

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st edition, Page no 167 .

questions.text: Which of the following pair of monosaccharides are present in lactulose?
questions.solution:
Disaccharides Monosaccharide unit
 Maltose glucose+glucose
Isomaltose glucose + glucose
Lactose galactose + glucose
Lactulose galactose + fructose
Sucrose glucose +fructose

Lactulose is a disaccharide composed of two simple sugars, galactose and fructose linked by a β-1,4-glycosidic linkage. Ref Harpers biochemistry 32nd edition Page 153

questions.text: A child presented with seizures, swallowing difficulty, hepatosplenomegaly, bone pain and recurrent fractures. On evaluation he had yellowish brown skin pigmentation, pancytopenia and the following X-ray of long bones. What could be the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Gaucher's disease.

Gaucher disease, the most prevalent lysosomal storage disorder. It is an autosomal recessive inborn error of metabolism caused by mutations in the glucocerebrosidase (GBA1) gene. Commonly seen presenting signs and symptoms are as follows:

- Painless hepatomegaly and splenomegaly
- Hypersplenism and pancytopenia
- Severe joint pains, most frequently affecting the hips and knees
- Impaired olfaction and cognition
- Severe convulsions, hypertonia, intellectual disability, and apnea
- Myoclonus, seizures, dementia, and ocular muscle apraxia
- Parkinsonism
- Osteoporosis, widening of the long bones, known as ‘Erlenmeyer flask deformities.
- Yellowish-brown skin pigmentation.

Ref- Nelson textbook of Pediatrics 20th edition Page 711

questions.text:
A 40-year-old patient was brought to the emergency room by his relatives in a state of agitation, impaired judgment, and combativeness. His spot blood glucose level was 45 mg/dL.
He gives history of regularly attending the gym and an episode binge drinking alcohol on an empty stomach. Which of the following is the likely cause of hypoglycemia in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient who had a history of alcohol intake presenting with hypoglycemia and a state of agitation, impaired judgment, and combativeness is suggestive of alcohol (ethanol) intoxication that inhibits the process of gluconeogenesis.
The oxidation of ethanol to acetate by dehydrogenases is accompanied by the reduction of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD*) to NADH. This will result in a high concentration of NADH, leading to an increased NADH/NAD+ ratio. Due to this, excess NADH increases two reactions- pyruvate to lactate and oxaloacetate to malate.
Both of these reactions lead to a decrease in pyruvate and oxaloacetate levels, which are substrates for gluconeogenesis.
Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd Edition • Page No. 255 .

questions.text: A patient was incidentally found to have essential fructosuria. Which of the following enzymes is deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
The cause of essential fructosuria is a hepatic fructokinase deficiency, which is inherited autosomally recessively. 

Fructose is not phosphorylated in the liver, it cannot be trapped, hence gets excreted in urine.

It is asymptomatic condition (No hypoglycemia, no hepatomegaly). Fructose appears in urine (detected by reducing sugar tests)

Other options:
Aldolase A – Present in muscle and RBCs; not involved in fructose metabolism
Aldolase B – Deficient in Hereditary Fructose Intolerance (HFI), which is symptomatic (vomiting, hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly)
Sucrase – Breaks down sucrose (not involved in primary fructose metabolism)


References:
1. Lippincott Illustrated Reviews: Biochemistry, 8th Edition, Page 138
2. Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page 190

questions.text: A neonate was brought with yellow sclera and hypoglycemia. He is exclusively breastfed. Urine Benedict's test is positive. Which of the following enzymes is most likely deficient in this neonate?
questions.solution:
This neonate presents with:

1. Jaundice (yellow sclera)
2. Hypoglycemia (liver damage due to accumulated products cause impaired gluconeogenisis and glycogenolysis)
3. Positive Benedict's test (indicates reducing sugars in urine)
4. Exclusively breastfed (milk contains lactose = glucose + galactose)

These features are classic for Classic Galactosemia, caused by Galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GALT) deficiency, leading to accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate which is toxic to liver, kidney, and brain.


 

other options:
1. Galactokinase – Milder form (no hypoglycemia or jaundice), presents mainly with cataracts
2. Lactose – It’s a sugar, not an enzyme
3. Glucose-6-phosphatase – Deficiency causes Von Gierke disease, presents later with hepatomegaly and lactic acidosis, not jaundice and reducing sugar in urine


Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 20th Edition, Page 973

questions.text:
Which of the following electron transport chain inhibitors is incorrectly matched with its corresponding complex?
a. Complex I - 1. Rotenone
b. Complex II - 2. BAL
c. Complex IV- 3.CO
d. Complex V - 4. Oligomycin
questions.solution:
The antidote for arsenic poisoning, BAL (British anti-lewisite), blocks Complex III(not complex II) of the electron transport chain (ETC)



Reference
1.Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd Edition , Page number. 127-128, 158
2.Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page a no 359

questions.text: Classical galactosemia Is due to a deficiency of which enzyme?
questions.solution:
Classical galactosemia: Key points

 

  • Deficient enzyme: Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT)

  • Inheritance: Autosomal recessive

  • Accumulated metabolite: Galactose-1-phosphate (toxic to liver, brain, kidney)

    Pathway affected:

Lactose → Galactose → (via Galactokinase) → Galactose-1-P → (via GALT) → UDP-galactose
Block at GALT = accumulation of Galactose-1-P

Clinical Features (appear after lactose feeding):

  • Jaundice

  • Hepatomegaly

  • Vomiting

  • Oil drop cataract (due to excess galactitol from alternate pathway)

  • E. coli sepsis (especially in neonates)

  • Failure to thrive

  • Intellectual disability if untreated

    Treatment:

  • Exclude galactose and lactose from diet


Reference: Harper's illustrated Biochemistry 31st edition page no 189

questions.text: Which of the following is not a function of glucagon?
questions.solution:
Glucagon is a catabolic hormone secreted by alpha cells of the pancreas during fasting or hypoglycemia. It raises blood glucose levels by promoting the following processes:
 

Function Effect
Gluconeogenesis Stimulates production of glucose from non-carbohydrate sources (e.g., amino acids, lactate)
Glycogenolysis Breaks down glycogen to release glucose
Ketogenesis Promotes formation of ketone bodies in the liver during prolonged fasting
Glycolysis Inhibited — glucagon inhibits glycolysis in the liver to prevent glucose usage



Insulin is responsible for glycolysis; glucagon does not.

Functions of glucagon and insulin:

During a fast, glucagon secretion increases and insulin release decreases when blood glucose levels fall.

Impact of elevated insulin:glucagon ratio on gluconeogenic and glycogenolysis enzymes:

1. It deactivates glycogen synthase and activates glycogen phosphorylase, the primary enzyme in glycogenolysis. As a result, the liver's glycogen reserves are quickly released for use as fuel.

2. It facilitates the creation of the enzyme glucose-6 phosphatase, which releases glucose from glucose-6 phosphate. Since the brain and red blood cells don't have mitochondria and are primarily dependent on glucose during fasting, they use the generated glucose.

3. Increased gluconeogenesis results from the induction of fructose-1, 6-bisphosphatase and phosphoenol pyruvate carboxykinase.

Reference: Harper's illustrated Biochemistry 31st edition page no 138,139,175

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy rapidly develops hypoglycemia after moderate activity. Blood examination reveals raised levels of ketone bodies, lactic acid, and triglycerides. On examination, the liver and kidneys are found to be enlarged. Which of the following deficiency would be seen in the liver of this child ?
questions.solution:
The child presents with:

  • Fasting hypoglycemia (especially after activity)

  • Hepatomegaly and renomegaly

  • Elevated lactic acid, triglycerides, and ketone bodies

This clinical scenario is classic for Von Gierke disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type I)


Symptoms:

* Severe low blood sugar levels
* Ketosis
* Build-up of lactic acid
* High levels of triglycerides
* Elevated uric acid levels

A conclusive identification is achieved through a liver biopsy. It is recommended to limit the intake of fructose and galactose in the diet.

Risks associated with von Gierke's disease include:

* Development of polycystic ovaries
* Reduced bone density (osteopenia)
* Growth of liver adenomas
* High blood pressure in the lungs
* Inflammation of the pancreas
* Failure of the kidneys.
Reference: Harper's illustrated Biochemistry 31st edition page no 167

questions.text: A neonate was brought with features of lethargy, and poor oral intake. On examination, a cataract was seen. Urine Benedict's test was positive but Image for Glucose given . What will be the enzyme deficiency in this condition?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario of a neonate presenting with lethargy, and poor oral intake, with examination revealing a cataract and urine benedict's test was positive but negative for glucose, is suggestive of classical galactosemia and enzyme deficient is galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase.
  • Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase deficiency leads to classical galactosemia. It is an autosomal recessive disorder. Normally, newborns receive up to 40% of their intake as lactose (glucose + galactose).
  • The deficiency of this enzyme leads to an inability to convert galactose-1-phosphate to uridine diphosphate galactose. This leads to the accumulation of galactose 1-phosphate and causes injury to the kidney, liver, and brain.
Reference: Harpar’s illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page No 189, 191.

questions.text: A child presents to you with bone pain, hepatosplenomegaly, and pancytopenia. A trephine biopsy aspirate shows the following finding. Which of the following is the most likely enzyme deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario of a child with bone pain, hepatosplenomegaly, and trephine biopsy showing Gaucher's cell with a characteristic crumpled tissue paper appearance is suggestive of Gaucher's disease.
  • The deficient enzyme is glucocerebrosidase (also known as beta-glucosidase). Gaucher's disease is an inborn error of metabolism caused due to a deficiency of beta-glucocerebrosidase.
  • It is the most common lysosomal storage disorder and the mode of inheritance is autosomal recessive.
  • There is an accumulation of lipid-laden macrophages in the spleen, liver, and other tissues.
  • There are three clinical subtypes - type l (chronic non-neuronopathic), type ll (acute neuronopathic), and type ll (intermediate). Clinical features include anemia, thrombocytopenia, hepatosplenomegaly, and neurological features depending on the subtype.
Reference: Harpar’s illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page No 235.

questions.text: The results of the tests for proteins, sugar, and ketones are listed below. Which of the following will show up as positive in urine when someone is starving?
questions.solution:
Only 3 will be positive in cases of starvation.

Test 1 - Biuret test for proteins
Test 2 - Benedicts test for reducing sugars
Test 3 - Rothera’s test for ketone bodies.

Higher than normal quantities of ketone bodies present in the blood or urine constitutes hyperketonemia or ketonuria, respectively. The overall condition is called ketosis. The basic form of ketosis occurs in starvation. Ketone bodies will be positive in starvation in the patient's urine.


In **diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA)**, both urine sugar and ketones are present, while in **starvation ketosis**, urine sugar is absent, but ketones are present.


Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 84.

questions.text: A child exhibits hypotonia and seizures. It was determined to be Zellweger syndrome. In the case of Zellweger syndrome, which of the following builds up in the brain?
questions.solution:
Peroxisomal disorders are a group of rare genetic conditions caused by problems in the formation or function of **peroxisomes**, which are small structures in cells responsible for breaking down fatty acids and other toxic substances.  

### Key Features
1. **Cause**: Genetic mutations affecting peroxisome formation or enzyme function.  
2. **Main Functions Affected**:  
   - Breakdown of very-long-chain fatty acids (VLCFAs).  
   - Production of essential lipids like plasmalogens (important for brain and lung function).  
3. **Common Symptoms**:  
   - Developmental delays.  
   - Neurological issues (e.g., seizures, muscle weakness).  
   - Liver problems and vision or hearing loss.  

### Examples of Peroxisomal Disorders:  
- **Zellweger Syndrome**: Severe disorder affecting peroxisome formation, often fatal in infancy.  
- **Adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD)**: Accumulation of VLCFAs affecting the brain and adrenal glands.  

Zellweger's (cerebrohepatorenal) syndrome is characterized by accumulation of very-long-chain fatty acids.

The unusual inherited absence of peroxisomes in all tissues is known as Zellweger's (cerebrohepatorenal) syndrome, and it affects some people. They display a broad loss of peroxisomal activities as well as an accumulation of C, Ca polyenoic acids in the brain tissue. Most victims of the illness pass away during the first year of life due to its severe neurological symptoms.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 225.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presented with chief complaints of severe pain in abdomen. He has multiple xanthomas on physical examination. A blood sample was drawn for testing, and the plasma in the sample appeared milky. Which lipoprotein is increased, out of the following?
questions.solution:
The symptoms are characteristic of hyperchylomicronemia.There will be increase in chylomicron and chylomicron remnants in the body but more prominent will be chylomicron.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 268.

questions.text:
LDL was found to be significantly raised in a patient's laboratory tests, while LDL receptor levels were normal.
Which of the following has the highest probability?
questions.solution:
Type Ila hypercholesterolemia individuals have extremely high levels of LDL and normal numbers of LDL receptors. Mutation in the apoB-100 ligand characterizes familial hypercholesterolemia.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 268.

choices.text: Increased activity of lipoprotein lipase and decreased activity of hormone sensitive lipase
Increased activity of hormone sensitive lipase and decreased activity of lipoprotein lipase

questions.text: Which of the following causes higher triglyceride and VLDL levels in uncontrolled diabetic mellitus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Increased activity of hormone sensitive lipase and decreased activity of lipoprotein lipase

Type 1 DM is characterized by deficiency of insulin in the body.
This results in generation of low insulin/glucagon ratio in the body.
Insulin is an inhibitor of hormone sensitive lipase. Therefore, deficiency of insulin will result in its overactivity in adipocytes resulting in increased breakdown of lipid into  fatty acids ( lipolysis ).



Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 146.

questions.text: What is likely accumulated in a child with hypotonia, hepatomegaly, and cerebrohepatorenal syndrome?
questions.solution:
The probable biochemical defect is the presence of very long chain fatty acids.
 
  • Those with a rare genetic lack of peroxisomes in all tissues suffer from Zellweger's (cerebrohepatorenal) syndrome.
  • Further to showing an all-over loss of peroxisomal activities, they also reveal an accumulation of C, C polyenoic acids in brain tissue.
  • The majority of patients pass away during the first year of birth due to the disease's severe neurological symptoms.
Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 225.

questions.text: Maximum cholesterol-containing food among the following is:
questions.solution:
Eggs contain the most cholesterol out of any food with 1234 mg per 100 gram serving, which is approximately 411% of the Daily Value (DV). If only the yolk is consumed, 210mg of cholesterol is consumed, which roughly makes up 70% of the DV. When the whole egg is consumed, the DV slightly increases to 212mg (around 71%).

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 259.

questions.text: Comparing HDL to other lipoproteins, which of the following is in highest concentration?
questions.solution:
Due to its "Largest Density" and minimal migration during electrophoresis, HDL has the highest percentage of apoproteins. Additionally, it has the most phospholipids.

Triacylglycerol is the predominant lipid in chylomicrons and VLDL, whereas cholesterol and phospholipid are the predominant lipids in LDL and HDL, respectively.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 248.

questions.text: Which of the following processes does not take place in the mitochondria?
questions.solution:
The cytosol is the only location where fatty acid synthesis occurs. 

In the mitochondria, fatty acids undergo beta oxidation.

In addition to producing its own mitochondrial DNA, mitochondria also participate in the folding and post-translational modifications of proteins.

To remember the reaction taking place in both Cytoplasm + Mitochondria- remember PUBG
P - Pyrimidine synthesis
U - Urea Cycle
B - Blood - Heme Synthesis
G - GLUCONEOGENESIS

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 139.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is not a component of the fatty acid synthase complex?
questions.solution:
Acetyl Co-1 carboxylase is the rate-limiting enzyme of fatty acid synthesis and is an enzyme, which is not a component of fatty acid synthase complex.

Mnemonic: ATC-KER (A Train Can Keep Elongating Reactions)

  1. A: Acetyl Transferase (AT)
    • Transfers acetyl group to the enzyme.
  2. T: Malonyl Transferase (MT)
    • Transfers malonyl group to the enzyme.
  3. C: Condensing Enzyme (CE)
    • Combines acetyl and malonyl groups, releasing CO₂.
  4. K: β-Ketoacyl Reductase (KR)
    • Reduces the β-keto group using NADPH.
  5. E: Enoyl Reductase (ER
    • Reduces the double bond using NADPH.
  6. R: Thioesterase (TE)
    • Releases the finished fatty acid (palmitate) from the complex.
Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 227.

questions.text: Which of the following is unable to make use of Ketone bodies?
questions.solution:
RBCs cannot utilize ketone bodies as they lack mitochondria.

The heart can make use of fatty acids in any state whereas the brain uses it only during periods of starvation.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 655.

questions.text: Which of the following is the byproduct of fatty acid production that is most prevalent?
questions.solution:
Fact based.
Palmitic acid is the most common byproduct of fatty acid production.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 207.

questions.text: Sphingomyelinase deficiency is associated with:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Niemann-pick disease

Autosomal recessive sphingolipidosis which occurs due to deficiency of sphingomyelinase and results in accumulation of sphingomyelin.
Key features-
  • Cherry red spot in macula
  • Zebra body inclusions on electron microscopy


Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 245.

questions.text: In electrophoresis, which of the following lipoproteins does not flow toward the charged end?
questions.solution:
Chylomicrons do not flow towards charged end because they have least percentage of polar apo proteins. 



Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 228.

questions.text: Rothera's test used for detection of
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Ketones

Tests for detecting ketone bodies-
  1. Rothera’s test-
  • Positive Rothera’s test is indicated by presence of purple ring at the junction of 2 liquids
  • It is positive in case of acetoacetate and acetone.
  1. Gerhardt’s test-
  • Positive test is indicated by presence of Bordeaux/port wine color subsequent to reaction between ferric chloride and acetoacetate in urine sample.
  • Positive in case of acetoacetate
  1. Ketostix-
  • Dipstick test to detect ketone bodies.
  • Positive in case of acetone and acetoacetate
Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 338.

questions.text:
Which of the following causes ketosis in type 1 diabetes?
A. Decreased beta-oxidation of fatty acids
B. Increased mobilisation of fatty acid from adipose tissue
C. Decreased acetyl CoA entering to the TCA cycle
D. Increased beta- hydroxy butyrate dehydrogenase
questions.solution:
There is deficiency of insulin in type 1 DM. As a result, insulin mediated glucose uptake is not possible in adipose tissue and muscle for energy source.

Therefore, stored fat in adipose tissue is mobilized for generation of FFAs by beta oxidation which serve as precursors for ketone body synthesis. 

Also, since acetyl Co-A generated from breakdown of FFAs are directed towards ketone body synthesis, less is available to undergo oxidation via Kreb's cycle. 

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 146.

questions.text: Which of the following lipids is not a substance that amphipathizes?

questions.text: Which substance most effectively inhibits the carnitine palmitate acyl transferase on the outer mitochondrial membrane in a well-fed state?
questions.solution:

questions.text: Which of the enzymatic processes below results in the production of both cholesterol and ketone bodies?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: HMG-Co-A Synthase

HMG CoA synthase catalyzes conversion of acetoacetyl CoA to HMG CoA ( 3 hydroxy 3 methylglutaryl CoA ), a step common to both ketogenesis and cholesterol synthesis.
However, in the pathway of ketogenesis, HMG CoA is further acted upon by the enzyme HMG CoA lyase which converts HMG CoA into acetoacetate whereas in cholesterol synthesis, HMG CoA is acted upon by HMG CoA reductase
(rate limiting enzyme) which converts HMG CoA to mevalonate.

questions.text:
A 4 year old male child presented to paediatrics OPD with anemia, thrombocytopenia and bony pain. On examination, hepatosplenomegaly was noticed. Bone marrow aspirate reveals " crumpled tissue paper " appearance.



What is the most likely enzyme defect in this condition?

A. Glucocerebrosidase
B. Sphingomyelinase
C. Hexosaminidase
D. Glucose-6-phosphatase
questions.solution:
• The clinical scenario is suggestive of Gaucher's disease. It is inherited in an autosomal recessive fashion and characterized by deficiency of the enzyme beta-glucocerebrosidase.
  • This leads to the accumulation of glucocerebroside in various organs, particularly the liver, spleen, and bone marrow. 
  • Accumulation in liver/spleen leads to Hepatsplenomegaly. 
  • Due to bone marrow involvement, patients often have pancytopenia. Bony involvement often leads to bony pains and avascualr necrosis.
Other options

Option B- Deficiency of sphingomyelinase results in Neimann Pick disease.

Option C- Deficiency of hexosaminidase causes Sandhoff disease.

Option D- Deficiency of glucose-6-phosphtase results in Von Gierke Disease-type 1 GSD. 


Reference: Nelson’s Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st edition, Page no 771-773.

questions.text: Burnt sugar smell of urine is due to the defect of?
questions.solution:
The "burnt sugar" or "maple syrup" smell of urine is characteristic of Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD).

  • This condition is caused by a defect in the enzyme branched-chain keto acid dehydrogenase (BCKD), which is involved in the metabolism of branched-chain amino acids (leucine, isoleucine, and valine) i.e decarboxylation of the alpha-keto acids of leucine, isoleucine, and valine to their respective branched-chain acyl-CoAs.
 
  • The deficiency leads to the accumulation of these amino acids and their corresponding keto acids, resulting in the distinctive odor and neurological symptoms if untreated.



Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st edition, Page no 708, 709.

questions.text:
Refsum's disease is caused by the defect of? 
1. \(\beta-\) oxidation of branched-chain fatty acids 
2. \(\alpha-\)Oxidation of branched-chain fatty acids 
3. Omega oxidation of branched-chain fatty acids 
4. \(\alpha-\) oxidation of dicarboxylic acids
questions.solution:
• Refsum disease is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by defective peroxisomal alpha-oxidation of phytanic acid (phytates)
 
  • The accumulation of these fatty acids(phytanic acid) in the body causes vision problems, muscle/limb weakness, numbness, and discoordination/ataxia.


Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 30th edition, Page no 231

questions.text: Zellweger's syndrome is caused by defect of?
questions.solution:
• Zellweger syndrome belongs to a group of diseases called peroxisome biogenesis disorders (PBD). The diseases are caused by defects in any one of the PEX genes that are required for the normal formation and function of peroxisomes.

Zellweger syndrome is a rare congenital disorder caused by mutations in genes responsible for peroxisome biogenesis (commonly the PEX genes). These genes encode proteins essential for the formation and function of peroxisomes, which play a critical role in lipid metabolism and detoxification of hydrogen peroxide.


Clinical features:

  • Severe hypotonia (floppy baby syndrome).
  • Craniofacial abnormalities (high forehead, broad nasal bridge).
  • Hepatomegaly.
  • Developmental delay and seizures.
  • Early death, often within the first year of life.

The underlying defect is the inability to form functional peroxisomes, leading to the accumulation of very-long-chain fatty acids (VLCFAs) and other toxic metabolites.



Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st edition, Page no 215, 579.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct with regard to the response of adipose tissue to the low insulin-glucagon ratio?
questions.solution:
A low insulin/ glucagon ratio represents a person in the fasting state, and will result in metabolic modifications to provide energy to the tissues of the body. This is also seen in states of stress.

  • Hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) in the adipose tissue is activated during the fasting state.
  • HSL cleaves triacylglycerols (TAGs) into free fatty acids (FFAs) and glycerol. These FFAs can then be used as an energy source by other tissues in the body.
Reference: Harpar’s illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition, Page. No- 338, 358.

questions.text: There is an intracellular build up of cholesterol and cholesterol esters/fats in all of the following conditions except?
questions.solution:
Intracellular cholesterol/cholesteryl ester accumulation occurs in several disorders:

  • Strawberry gallbladder: Accumulation of cholesterol in the gallbladder mucosa → "strawberry" appearance.

  • Tendon xanthomas: Cholesterol and cholesteryl esters deposited in tendons, commonly seen in familial hypercholesterolemia.

  • Niemann-Pick disease: Lysosomal storage disorder causing accumulation of sphingomyelin and cholesterol in macrophages.

Abetalipoproteinemia:

  • Caused by mutation in MTP (microsomal triglyceride transfer protein) → impaired assembly of chylomicrons and VLDL.

  • Leads to fat malabsorption and vitamin deficiencies, but there is no intracellular cholesterol/cholesteryl ester accumulation. Instead, cells are cholesterol-deficient.

Hence, the condition without intracellular cholesterol accumulation is abetalipoproteinemia.

questions.text: A defect in which of the following leads to familial dysbetalipoproteinemia or type Ill hyperlipoproteinemia ?
questions.solution:
• Defects in apo-E lead to type Ill hyperlipoproteinemia / familial dysbetalipoproteinemia.
  • It is characterized by defective clearance of chylomicron remnants and intermediate-density lipoproteins by the liver
  • This leads to hypercholesterolemia, xanthomas, and atherosclerosis.
  • Defective apo-C Il results in type I hyperlipoproteinemia/ familial lipoprotein lipase deficiency.
  • Familial hypercholesterolemia occurs due to a defect in the LDL receptor.
Reference: Harpar’s illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page No 268.
Reference: Harrison Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 3140-3141.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy with type 1 diabetes mellitus presents with unconsciousness. His urine is subjected to a test and the results are shown below. What is the test done?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of diabetic ketoacidosis. Rothera‘s test, as shown in the image, is a specific test used to detect the presence of ketone bodies in urine.

Type 1 diabetes mellitus is characterized by low insulin levels, leading to increased conversion of fatty acids into acetyl-CoA, which in turn results in elevated ketone body production. Ketosis can be confirmed by detecting ketone bodies in the urine using Rothera's test.

The test involves saturating 5 mL of urine with solid ammonium sulfate. A few drops of freshly prepared sodium nitroprusside are then added, followed by 2 mL of liquor ammonia poured along the sides of the test tube. The formation of a purple ring indicates the presence of ketone bodies. Similar strip tests based on this principle are also available.



Reference : DM Vasudevan Textbook Of Biochemistry for Medical Students, 7th Edition, Page no 138,166,365,429 .

questions.text: Ketone bodies are not utilised by the liver because it lacks:
questions.solution:
The liver does not utilize ketone bodies because it lacks the enzyme thiophorase.

Ketone bodies are produced in the liver's mitochondria through ketogenesis and are transported via the blood to peripheral tissues for use. The process of ketone body utilization involves the following steps:

1. Beta-hydroxybutyrate, the most common ketone body, is oxidized to acetoacetate by the enzyme beta-hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase, producing NADH.

2. Acetoacetate is then converted to acetoacetyl CoA by transferring a CoA molecule from succinyl CoA via the enzyme succinyl CoA-acetoacetyl CoA transferase (thiophorase).

3. Acetoacetyl CoA is then split into two acetyl CoA molecules by the enzyme thiolase, which are further oxidized to CO2 in the TCA cycle.

Thiokinase (also known as acyl-CoA synthetase) catalyzes the only energy-consuming step in fatty acid oxidation. In the presence of ATP and coenzyme A, thiokinase converts fatty acids into acyl-CoA, the active form of fatty acids. This reaction uses one high-energy phosphate, producing AMP and PPi.

When ketone bodies are present in higher-than-normal levels in the blood or urine, the conditions are known as ketonemia and ketonuria, respectively, and the overall condition is called ketosis. In pathological states such as starvation and diabetes mellitus, the excessive production of ketone bodies leads to ketosis. The ongoing buffering and excretion of ketone bodies deplete the body's alkali reserves, resulting in ketoacidosis.

 

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st edition, Page no 207-211 .

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of muscle weakness to the OPD. The doctor found that he has cardiomyopathy and diagnosed him to be a case of Barth Syndrome, where the patient has mitochondrial dysfunction. What is the defect in this patient?
questions.solution:
Decreased levels or altered metabolism of cardiolipin result in mitochondrial dysfunction, as observed in Barth syndrome (cardioskeletal myopathy). This condition is characterized by an enlarged and weakened heart (dilated cardiomyopathy), weakness in muscles used for movement (skeletal myopathy), recurrent infections due to low white blood cell counts (neutropenia), and short stature.

Cardiolipin, also known as diphosphatidyl glycerol, is a phospholipid found exclusively in the mitochondria. It is notable for its antigenic properties and can cause a false-positive result in the VDRL test.

This phospholipid is crucial for the inner mitochondrial membrane, where it plays a key role in:

° Ensuring the optimal function of various mitochondrial enzymes involved in energy metabolism.

Preserving the structural integrity of the mitochondrial membrane.


 

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st edition, Page no 118,200,201,230 .

questions.text: Which of the following is most beneficial in the prevention of coronary artery diseases?
questions.solution:
Omega-3 fatty acids such as alpha-linolenic acid (ALA), eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA), and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) are highly beneficial for preventing coronary artery diseases.

Sources and Benefits
Sources: Rich dietary sources of omega-3 fatty acids include plant oils (like flaxseed and canola), fish oils, and algal oils.
Anti-inflammatory Effects: These fatty acids exhibit anti-inflammatory properties, likely due to their ability to promote the production of less inflammatory prostaglandins and leukotrienes compared to omega-6 fatty acids.
Health Benefits
Omega-3 fatty acids contribute to cardiovascular health by:

Suppressing cardiac arrhythmias
Reducing plasma triacylglycerol levels
Decreasing the tendency for thrombosis
Lowering blood pressure
Significantly reducing the risk of cardiovascular mortality
Additionally, they are beneficial for other chronic degenerative diseases, including cancer, rheumatoid arthritis, and Alzheimer's disease.

questions.text: Zellweger syndrome is caused due to the defect of which of the following structures
questions.solution:
Zellweger syndrome is also known as cerebrohepatorenal syndrome. It is caused by mutations in the PEX family of genes causing a defect in the biogenesis of peroxisomes.This results in defective beta-oxidation of very long-chain fatty acids, defective alpha oxidation, and impaired synthesis of bile acids and plasmalogens.
The child presents with
• Dysmorphic facial features.
• Weakness, hypotonia.
• Neonatal seizures
• Eye abnormalities. Ref- Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry 31st edition • Page no: 215,579

questions.text: Cardiolipin can be found in which of the following locations?
questions.solution:
Cardiolipin can be found in inner mitochondrial membrane – where the electron transport chain (ETC) and ATP synthase are located. It stabilizes protein complexes involved in oxidative phosphorylation (e.g., complexes I–IV of the ETC)
It is a unique diphosphatidylglycerol lipid with four fatty acid chains.

Clinical correlation:
1. Anticardiolipin antibodies are seen in Antiphospholipid Syndrome.
2. Barth syndrome involves defective cardiolipin remodeling → leads to cardiomyopathy and skeletal myopathy


(Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st edition - Pages 118, 201, 230)

questions.text: A 1.5 kg male baby was delivered vaginally at 32 weeks of gestation. The infant was cyanotic and required CPAP immediately after delivery. His chest radiograph is shown below. A deficiency of which of the following phospholipids in the lungs is the likely cause for the condition?
questions.solution:
The case describes a preterm infant (32 weeks) with:

1. Cyanosis and respiratory distress
2. Chest X-ray showing a “ground-glass appearance”

Clinical features and Xray is suggestive of Neonatal Respiratory Distress Syndrome (NRDS).It is caused by surfactant deficiency in preterm infants.The main component of surfactant is lecithin (Dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine). In order to improve alveolar compliance, surfactant—which is secreted by type 2 pneumocytes in the alveoli—works to lower surface tension at the air-liquid interface.

Lecithin:Sphingomyelin ratio < 2 in amniotic fluid= increased risk of NRDS

Management: Surfactant therapy or antenatal steroids (betamethasone)


Other options:
Phosphatidylserine – Involved in apoptosis signaling
Diphosphatidylglycerol – Another name for cardiolipin, found in mitochondria
Phosphatidylinositol – Involved in signaling pathways


Reference
1.Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics 20th Edition - Pg: 851
2.Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry 31st edition - Pg: 229-230, 234

questions.text: Which of the following hormones have an inhibitory effect on hormone-sensitive lipase?
questions.solution:
Hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) is inhibited by insulin and leptin, whereas its activity is stimulated by the other hormones mentioned in the choices.
Adipose tissue secretes the hormone leptin in proportion to body fat, which acts as a long-term energy balance regulator.

Actions of Leptin:
1. central effects- affects hypothalamus, to regulate hunger and energy consumption. Reduced appetite and increased energy expenditure are two ways that leptin helps keep body weight within a steady range.
2. peripheral effects- inhibits HSL activity, hence adipocytes' ability to break down triglycerides into fatty acids is reduced, which lowers the amount of free fatty acids released into the bloodstream.


Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Pages 138, 139, 175.

questions.text: Cholesterol is synthesized primarily from__.
questions.solution:
Cholesterol is made primarily in the liver, adrenal glands, testes, ovaries, and intestines.

The process of making cholesterol involves some of its key steps taking place in the endoplasmic reticulum and others in the cell's cytoplasm. The main enzyme responsible for controlling the production of cholesterol in the body is HMG CoA reductase.

HMG-CoA is converted to mevalonate by NADPH through a reaction facilitated by HMG CoA reductase, which is the key step in the cholesterol synthesis pathway. This is where cholesterol-lowering statins come into play, as they inhibit the activity of HMG CoA reductase.

The long-term control of cholesterol production involves managing the production of HMG CoA reductase. When there's enough cholesterol in the cell, the production of HMG CoA reductase is reduced, leading to less cholesterol being made.

Cholesterol also plays a role in controlling the production of HMG CoA reductase. When cholesterol levels are low, enzymes in the Golgi bodies cut a sterol regulatory element-binding protein (SREBP), forming a protein that binds to a sterol regulatory element (SRE) on the DNA. This binding activates the transcription of the HMG CoA reductase gene, which in turn increases the production of cholesterol.

Key steps in Cholesterol synthesis: 
 
Step Reaction
1. Acetyl-CoA → Acetoacetyl-CoA
2. Acetoacetyl-CoA + Acetyl-CoA → HMG-CoA
3. HMG-CoA → Mevalonate (via HMG-CoA reductase, rate-limiting step)
4. Mevalonate → → → Cholesterol (through isoprenoid intermediates)


Hormones that affect HMG reductase include:

* Insulin and thyroxine boost the activity of HMG CoA reductase.

* Cortisol and glucagon slow down the activity of HMG CoA reductase.

* Statins reduce the activity of HMG CoA reductase.

Other options: 

  • Oxaloacetate: Involved in gluconeogenesis, not cholesterol synthesis

  • Malonyl-CoA: Intermediate in fatty acid synthesis, not cholesterol

  • Pyruvate: Precursor to acetyl-CoA, but not a direct substrate for cholesterol synthesis


Reference: Harper's illustrated Biochemistry 31st edition page no 250

questions.text: Which of the following cycle is not present in muscle?
questions.solution:
• Ketogenesis 

    • This occurs only in the liver, specifically in mitochondria of hepatocytes.

    • Muscles do not perform ketogenesis; they use ketone bodies but do not produce them.

  • Glycogenesis 

    • Muscles store glucose as glycogen, so glycogenesis is active in skeletal muscle.

  • Lipolysis 

    • Muscles contain some triglycerides and can carry out lipolysis, although the major site is adipose tissue.

    • Additionally, muscle uses free fatty acids from circulation for energy.

  • Glycogenolysis 

    • Muscle breaks down glycogen to glucose-6-phosphate for local energy use, especially during exercise.

    • Unlike liver, muscle lacks glucose-6-phosphatase, so it cannot release free glucose into the blood


Reference: Harper's illustrated Biochemistry 31st edition page no 201-202

questions.text: A patient with a family history of coronary heart disease presented with tendon xanthomas. His lipid profile showed serum LDL to be 280 mg/dL and triglyceride levels was 398 mg/dl. What is the likely defect in this patient?
questions.solution:
• The clinical presentation with tendon xanthomas, elevated serum LDL and elevated serum triglycerides points to a diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia and is due to a defect in LDL receptors.
  • Familial hypercholesterolemia (type lla hyperlipoproteinemia) is an inherited disorder due to defects in LDL receptors. This defect causes a decrease in the uptake of LDL and cholesterol.
  • Xanthomas are tumorous masses produced by foamy cell clusters (lipid-laden macrophages) found in the connective tissue of the skin and in tendons.
  • Diagnosis is done clinically based on hypercholesterolemia with • LDL > 190 mg/dl, • Family history of hypercholesterolemia and/or • Premature coronary artery disease.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 9th Edition, Page No 62.

questions.text: Which of the following forms of collagen is found in basement membrane?
questions.solution:
The majority of the collagen in the basement membrane is type IV collagen. Between underlying epithelial and endothelial cells, it is a network-forming collagen that serves as a partition between tissue compartments.

questions.text: What does the selenocysteine codon look like?
questions.solution:
The amino acid selenocysteine, also known as the "21st amino acid," is not explicitly coded for in the genetic code, unlike the other amino acids found in biological proteins. Instead, a UGA codon, which is often a stop codon, is used to encode it. This method is known as translational recoding.
Pyrolysine "22nd amino acid" is encoded by stop codon UAG. 
Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 18.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a protein precipitation technique?
questions.solution:
Protein precipitation does not require titration with reducing sugar.
Protein precipitation can be done by
1.isoelectric method
2.salting in and salting out
3.precipitation method
4.using heavy metals
5.chromatographic methods

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 25.

questions.text: Which will be advantageous to patients with Gyrate Atrophy and a deficient Ornithine Transcarbamoylase?
questions.solution:
Gyrate atrophy is a retinal degenerative disease that is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme Ornithine Transcarbamoylase (OTC). This enzyme is responsible for converting ornithine, an amino acid, into other metabolic compounds, such as urea and citrulline.

When the enzyme is deficient, ornithine accumulates and leads to a buildup of waste compounds in the retina, causing various retinal degenerative effects.

Patients with Gyrate atrophy are often advised to follow an arginine-free diet, as arginine is a precursor to ornithine. By restricting the amount of arginine in their diet, they reduce the amount of ornithine in the body and thus the buildup of waste products in the retina, thus improving their condition.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 292.

questions.text: Which of these amino acids has a positive charge at physiological pH?
questions.solution:
Arginine has a positive charge at physiological pH because it possesses ‘guanidino’ group which has additional nitrogen atoms to attain positive charge.

Rest of the options do not have negative charge at physiological pH.

questions.text: Which of these does not precipitate protein?
questions.solution:
Proteins are less soluble at their isoelectric point where they have zero net charge and can most easily approach each other with minimal charge repulsion. The isoelectric point is the pH of a solution at which the net primary charge of a protein becomes zero.

questions.text: What is serotonin also known as?

questions.text: Which of the following deficiencies causes phenylketonuria?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Phenylalanine hydroxylase ( PAH)
