questions.text: In which of the aminoacid replacements, its normal charge is not altered?
questions.solution:
In this question, the idea of conservative or homologous replacement of amino acids is covered. 
If a substituted amino acid falls under the same classification like hydrophobic or hydrophilic, its function will not change.
Since glutamine and asparagine are both uncharged polar (hydrophilic) amino acids, the right response is glutamine to asparagine. As a result, there is no change in the polarity or charge of the peptide/protein when asparagine is substituted.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews Biochemistry, 5th edition, Page no 4.

questions.text: Which is a deficiency amidst the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The image is representative of the Casals necklace, which is seen in pellagra and denotes tryptophan deficiency.
Pellagra can occur due to:
Vitamin B3 (Niacin)- which is produced from tryptophan and requires vitamins B2 and B6 for its production, may contribute to pellagra.
Hartnups disease: Tryptophan malabsorption is caused by Hartnups disease, which is caused by a defect in the membrane transport of tryptophan across PCT and enterocytes. A tryptophan deficiency results from this.
Carcinoid syndrome: Increased serotonin production causes tryptophan to be diverted away from the NAD+ pathway.
Vitamin B6 deficiency: Niacin production is hampered in cases of vitamin B6 insufficiency due to deficient kynureninase.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews Biochemistry, 5th edition, Page no 380.

questions.text: The following conditions have deficient branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase
questions.solution:
Maple syrup urine disease is a disorder of branched chain amino acids valine, leucine and isoleucine which occurs due to deficiency of the enzyme branched chain ketoacid dehydrogenase. Results in accumulation of branched chain keto acids leading to Fatal ketoacidosis Mental Retardation Increased alpha keto acids in blood Characteristic maple syrup odor of urine Treatment- Diet lacking in branched chain amino acids.

Hartnup disease is a neutral amino acid transporter defect that leads to urinary excretion of amino acids.

Alkaptonuria is cause deposition black alkapton bodies in pinna, cartilages, sclera called oochronosis. 

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews Biochemistry, 5th edition, Page no 272.

questions.text:
A patient reports knee pain. Routine investigations turn up nothing extraordinary, yet the patient is still not satisfied.
When standing, urine turns black. Which enzyme is responsible for it?
questions.solution:
The patient is most probably suffering from Alkaptonuria, in which there is a deficiency of the enzyme Homogentisate Oxidase.
Clinical features of the disease include:
  • Garrod’s Tetrad of - Alkaptonuria, Albinis, Pentosuria, Cystinuria
  • Normal Life till 3-4 Decade (Urine Darkening on standing is the only symptom in children)
  • Ochronosis - Pigmentation d/t Alkapton Bodies
  • Arthritis
Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews Biochemistry, 5th edition, Page no 274.

questions.text: Which amino acid should be supplemented in a patient with cystathionine B synthase deficiency?
questions.solution:
Because Cystathioninase helps break down Cystathionine into Cysteine and Homoserine.
Because cysteine cannot be generated when cystathionine beta synthase is deficient, cysteine must be added to the diet as a supplement.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews Biochemistry, 5th edition, Page no 273.

questions.text: In order to detoxify ammonia in the brain, the following compound is formed:
questions.solution:
Ammonia is detoxified in brain by leading to formation of glutamine.

In all the tissues in body ammonia is detoxified by combination with glutamate leading to formation of glutamine
Except muscles where the carrier is alanine instead of glutamine.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 279.

choices.text: Net loss of muscle protein due to increased break-down
Leakage from cells due to membrane damage

questions.text: What is the main cause of increased serum levels of alanine after a fast?
questions.solution:
Increased levels of alanine in serum after fasting are primarily due to net loss of muscle protein due to increased breakdown.
Alanine is synthesized and secreted from the skeletal muscle that is used as substrates of gluconeogenesis in the liver.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 282.

questions.text: As people get older, there is cognitive impairment because of elevated levels of:
questions.solution:
With ageing, a slight decrease in cognitive impairment is seen due to increase in level of homocysteine.

Features associated with congnitive impairment (dementia) in the elderly are:
￲high level of plasma homocysteine
￲low level of plasma folate and vitamin B12￲

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 375.

choices.text: Most of the sulphur is in inorganic sulphate ion form
Cysteine and methionine are sulphur containing amino acids

questions.text: Which of the following claims about sulfur metabolism in the body is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Most of the sulphur is in inorganic sulphate ion form
 
  • Most of the sulfur in the body is in organic form in the form of amino acids methionine ( thioether linkage ) and cysteine (sulfhydryl/thioalcohol)-Option A and B.
  • Sulfur forms an essential component of mucopolysaccharides such as heparin-Option C
  • S-adenosyl methionine acts as a principle methyl donor for transmethylation reaction-an example of conjugation reaction-Option D
Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 99.

choices.text: Predominant porphyrin excreted in the urine is uroporphyrin
Pyrrole rings in porphyrinogen are joined together by methylene bonds

questions.text: The following statement regarding porphyrins is correct:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: All of the above are correct 

Option A-Porphyrinogens absorb light at 400 nm which is known as soret band.
Option B-Since uroporphyrin is water soluble; it is the predominant porphyrin which is excreted in urine. On the other hand, protoporphyrin is insoluble in water and therefore excreted in feces.
Option C-Four pyrrole rings connected by methylene bridges along with iron in ferrous (Fe2+) state constitutes heme protein.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 315.

questions.text: In transamination reactions, Aspartate is transaminated to which form?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Oxaloacetate 



Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 159.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids is most likely to cluster on the surface of a globular protein in the plasma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Lysine

Polar amino acids occupy the surface of a globular protein which is in contact with blood whereas non-polar amino acids tend to occupy the central hydrophobic core.
Examples of non-polar amino acids
  • Branched chain amino acids-Leucine, isoleucine and valine
  • Aromatic amino acids-Phenylalanine, tyrosine, tryptophan ( not histidine )
  • Sulfur containing amino acids-Methionine
  • Alanie
  • Proline
Rest of the amino acids constitute polar group.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews Biochemistry, 5th edition, Page no 2.

questions.text: The steroid nucleus of bile acids is conjugated to which of the following amino acids?
questions.solution:
Option 1 which states that the steroid nucleus of bile acids is conjugated to glycine and taurine is the correct option.
  • The steroid nucleus of bile acids is conjugated to the amino acids glycine and taurine.
  • Bile acids are synthesized from cholesterol in the liver and secreted into the small intestine to aid in the digestion and absorption of dietary fats.
  • The steroid nucleus of bile acids consists of four fused rings, and the molecule also contains a hydroxyl group and a carboxylic acid group.
  • In the liver, bile acids are conjugated with either glycine or taurine to form glycine conjugated bile acids or taurine conjugated bile acids, respectively.
  • Conjugation with these amino acids increases the water solubility of the bile acids, which facilitates their excretion in the urine and prevents their accumulation in the body. 
Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 265.

questions.text: Exclusive amino acids for ketosis include:
questions.solution:
Two amino acids(leucine and lysine)give rise to acetyl co A and hence are known as ketogenic amino acids.

Trick to memorize:- 
Ketogenic- Leucine 
Both Ketogenic and Glucogenic- PITTL 
P- Phenylalanine
I- Isoleucine
T- Tyrosine
T- Tryptophan
L- Lysine( predominantly ketogenic) 

Rest all amino acids are purely glucogenic 

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 142.

questions.text: What is linked to a homogentisic acid oxidase deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Alkaptonuria

Alkaptonuria is an autosomal recessive disorder which occurs due to deficiency of enzyme homogentisate oxidase causing impaired conversion of homogentisate to malylacetic acid.
The accumulated homogentisate gets converted to benzoquinone which then polymerizes to form alkapton bodies.
These alkapton bodies cause black discoloration of urine on long standing.
Clinical features-
  • Blac/reddish discoloration of diaper in infants with absent mental retardation.
  • Back pain, pigmentation and ochronosis in adults.
Alkaptonuria along with cystinnuria, albinism and essential pentosuria constitute Garrod’s tetrad.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 296.

questions.text: Which of the following in Eukaryotes is not subject to protein kinase phosphorylation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Asparagine 

Protein kinase phosphorylation requires presence of functional hydroxy (-OH) group in an amino acid.
Examples of hydroxy group containing amino acids-
  • Serine
  • Threonine
  • Tyrosine
Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 16.

questions.text: In a protein, which of the following amino acids frequently functions as a possible O-Glycosylation site for the attachment of an oligosaccharide unit?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Serine

O-glycosylation for attachment of an oligosaccharide unit requires presence of functional hydroxy (-OH) group in an amino acid.
Examples of hydroxy group containing amino acids-
  • Serine
  • Threonine
  • Tyrosine
Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 554.

questions.text: Except for _______, all of the following assays are used to estimate total serum protein.
questions.solution:
Bromocresol is not used for total serum protein estimation. Bromocresol green is used for only albumin estimation. 

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 5.

questions.text: A protein solution on heating forms a precipitate at about 40°C which redissolves at higher temperature. This solution is likely to contain:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Bence Jones Protein

Bence Jones proteins are immunoglobulin light chain (kappa>lambda) found in urine in multiple myeloma due to decreased filtration capability secondary to renal failure.
They have a property of forming a precipitate on heating urine specimen at 40 degree C which redissolves at higher temperature. This property was used historically in the diagnosis of multiple myeloma.
However, it has now been replaced with serum free light chain assays which are more sensitive in detecting even low levels of monoclonal free light chains.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology,10th edition, Page no 609.

questions.text: Which of the following is the Rate limiting enzyme for Urea Cycle?
questions.solution:
Correct Option 1:Carbonyl Phosphate Synthetase I 
 
  • The urea cycle is a series of biochemical reactions that take place in the liver, which converts toxic ammonia to urea, a compound that can be safely excreted by the body.
  • The rate-limiting enzyme for the urea cycle is Carbonyl Phosphate Synthetase I  that catalyzes the formation of carbamoyl phosphate from ammonia and bicarbonate. This reaction is the first step in the urea cycle.
Other options
  • Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase II (CPS II) is also a mitochondrial enzyme, but it is involved in the biosynthesis of pyrimidine nucleotides, not the urea cycle.
  • Isocitrate dehydrogenase is an enzyme involved in the citric acid cycle, which is responsible for the production of ATP in the mitochondria; It is not involved in the urea cycle.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 286.

questions.text: What carries out the proper folding of newly synthesised proteins in endoplasmic reticulum?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Chaperone 

Chaperons are a type of heat shock protein which assist in protein folding.
Mechanism of Action
  • Bind to short sequences of hydrophobic amino acids of extended polypeptide.
  • Thereby, they effectively shield the new polypeptide being synthesized from aggregating providing them with an opportunity to form an appropriate secondary structure.
Improper functioning of chaperons results in protein misfolding diseases such as
  • Prion disease: Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease and bovine spongiform encephalopathy.
  • Alzheimer’s disease
  • Beta thalassemia
Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 42.

questions.text: The reason for buffering capacity of some proteins and hemoglobin is -
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Histidine 

The pKA of histidine group in hemoglobin (6.7) is close to that of blood pH as compared to other amino acids. Therefore, it has excellent buffering capacity.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 55.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acid is not restricted in the diet in a patient suffering from Maple syrup urine disease?
questions.solution:
• Methionine is not restricted in Maple syrup urine disease.
  • Maple syrup urine disease (MSUD) is caused by a deficiency of branched-chain alpha-keto acid dehydrogenase complex (BCKDC).
  • The BCKDC is responsible for breaking down the branched-chain amino acids leucine, isoleucine, and valine. Therefore, these three amino acids are restricted in the diet of individuals with this condition. However, methionine metabolism is not affected and can be consumed as part of a normal diet.

Reference : Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 31st edition , Page no 566 .

questions.text: Deamination of methylated cytosine will form?
questions.solution:
• Deamination involves the removal of an amino group (-NH2) from the cytosine molecule, which results in the formation of uracil.
  • However, since the starting material, methylated cytosine, has a methyl group (-CH3) attached to the nitrogen atom that would normally be deaminated, the deamination reaction results in the conversion of methylated cytosine to thymine.


Reference : Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 31st edition , Page no 335,370.

questions.text: A child presents with blindness and hypotonia. On examination, there is no hepatomegaly. Fundoscopy revealed a cherry red spot. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A child with a cherry red spot on examination with concomitant neurological abnormalities such as blindness and hypotonia raises suspicion for a lysosomal storage disorders.

  • The cherry red spot observed on fundoscopy is a hallmark of gangliosidosis due to the accumulation of ganglioside (GM2 in Tay Sachs) in the ganglion cells of the retina.
  • It is not seen in Gaucher disease or Hurler syndrome, while Niemann Pick disease is a close differential.
  • However, Niemann Pick disease has prominent hepatosplenomegaly, which is classically absent in Tay Sachs disease, thus clinching our diagnosis.
Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 20th Edition, Page. No- 708, 3054.

questions.text: An alcoholic patient presents with acute gouty arthritis. Which of these would be found in the blood?
questions.solution:
High urate and lactate are to be found in the blood of the given paitent.

The patient presents with an acute flare of gout, in the setting of chronic alcoholism, as indicated by the vignette.

Central to ethanol metabolism and its pathologies is the increased [NADH]/ [NAD+] redox potential (Hence, option 1 is incorrect), which is due to the oxidation of ethanol by alcohol dehydrogenase leading to excess production of NADH.

 

Ethanol metabolism causes increased NADH/NAD+ ratio in the liver, causing:
1. Lactic acidosis due to increased pyruvate conversion to lactate.
2. Fasting hypoglycemia due to decreased gluconeogenesis due to more conversion of OAA to malate
3. Ketoacidosis due to the diversion of acetyl-CoA into ketogenesis rather than the TCA cycle
4. Lactate is known to increase renal urate reabsorption thereby decreasing its excretion by the kidneys and causing hyperuricemia. 

Reference: Harpar’s illustrated Biochemistry, 31th Edition, Page. No- 214,411.

questions.text: What is the cause of black urine in infancy?
questions.solution:
Dark staining of diapers or black urine in infants can be a characteristic symptom of an autosomal recessive amino acid metabolism defect, Alkaptonuria.

  • It is caused by the deficiency of homogentisic acid oxidase, leading to the accumulation of homogentisic acid.
  • This acid is oxidized to benzoquinone acetic acid and excreted in the urine, which on exposure to air turns black.
The condition has three characteristic symptoms:
  1. Homogentisic aciduria (the urine contains elevated levels of HA, which is oxidized to a dark pigment on standing,)
  2. Early onset of arthritis in the large joints
  3. Deposition of black pigment (ochronosis) in cartilage and collagenous tissue

Reference: Harpar’s illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition, Page. No- 304.

questions.text: Niacin is synthesized from?
questions.solution:
• Precursor for Niacin: The amino acid tryptophan serves as the precursor for niacin (vitamin B3) and is coded by the UGA codon in mitochondrial DNA.

• Conversion: Tryptophan can be converted into niacin, with approximately 60 mg of tryptophan yielding 1 mg of dietary niacin (as NADH and NAD+). Additionally, tryptophan is also involved in the synthesis of serotonin and melatonin.

• Clinical Correlation: Deficiency of the enzyme kynureninase or insufficient vitamin B6 can lead to niacin deficiency, resulting in symptoms similar to pellagra (such as dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia) and xanthurenic aciduria.
 

Other amino acids:

  • Tyrosine: Precursor for catecholamines and melanin.

  • Histidine: Precursor for histamine.

  • Arginine: Precursor for nitric oxide, urea, and creatine.

Hence, niacin is synthesized from tryptophan.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids contain a benzyl ring?
questions.solution:
A benzyl ring refers to a phenyl group attached through a –CH₂– side chain.
Phenylalanine has a classic benzyl side chain (–CH₂–C₆H₅).
Tyrosine is a hydroxylated derivative of phenylalanine, retaining the benzyl structure.
Tryptophan contains an indole ring, which includes a benzene ring fused with a pyrrole ring—thus also aromatic in nature.

Therefore, phenylalanine, tyrosine, and tryptophan all possess aromatic rings derived from benzyl or related structures.

questions.text:
Which of the following amino acids are essential for purine ring formation?
A. Glycine
B. Asparagine
C. Glutamine
D. Aspartate
E. Valine
questions.solution: • Glycine, aspartate, and glutamine are the amino acids that contribute to the synthesis of a purine ring. These amino acids play essential roles in the formation of purines, which are crucial components of nucleotides in DNA and RNA.

questions.text: Defective Tyrosine transaminase is associated with?
questions.solution:
Tyrosinemias are inherited disorders of tyrosine metabolism, classified into three types based on the enzyme defect and clinical presentation:

  • Type 1 Tyrosinemia: Defect in fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase → severe liver disease, renal tubular dysfunction.

  • Type 2 Tyrosinemia (Richner-Hanhart syndrome): Defect in tyrosine aminotransferase (tyrosine transaminase) → keratitis, painful palmoplantar hyperkeratosis, and mental retardation.

  • Type 3 Tyrosinemia: Defect in 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase → neurological symptoms.

  • Alkaptonuria: Defect in homogentisate oxidase → accumulation of homogentisic acid, ochronosis.

Key point:
Defective tyrosine transaminase specifically leads to Type 2 Tyrosinemia, characterized mainly by ocular and skin lesions, with less severe liver involvement.

questions.text: At physiological PH, buffering action in blood is caused by which amino acid
questions.solution:
Histidine plays a key role in buffering blood at physiological pH (~7.4) due to the imidazole side chain, which has a pKa around 6.0–6.5, allowing it to accept or donate protons near physiological pH.

Key points:

  • Found abundantly in hemoglobin, contributing to intracellular buffering.

  • Helps maintain acid-base homeostasis in blood and tissues.

  • Other amino acids like methionine, glycine, and arginine do not have side chains with pKa near physiological pH, so their buffering capacity is limited at pH 7.4.

questions.text: Which of the following is a purine analog used in treating gout?
questions.solution:
Allopurinol is a purine analog used in the treatment of gout and hyperuricemia.

Key points:

  • Mechanism: Inhibits xanthine oxidase, preventing the conversion of hypoxanthine → xanthine → uric acid, thereby lowering serum uric acid levels.

  • Clinical use:

    • Chronic gout

    • Tumor lysis syndrome prevention

    • Hyperuricemia in certain metabolic disorders

  • Other options:

    • Febuxostat: Non-purine xanthine oxidase inhibitor

    • Capecitabine & Cytarabine: Chemotherapy agents, not related to uric acid metabolism

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme deficiency causes maple syrup urine disease?
questions.solution:
• Branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase deficiency results in maple syrup urine disease.
  • There is defective oxidative decarboxylation of leucine, isoleucine and valine. The disease is characterized by feeding problems, ketoacidosis, changes in muscle tone, and coma.

Other options:
  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency causes congenital lactic acidosis.
  • Defective transketolase is a rare disorder of pentose phosphate metabolism causing developmental, intellectual disability, delayed or absent speech, short stature, and congenital heart defects.
  • Isocitrate dehydrogenase is an enzyme of the TCA cycle which converts isocitrate to alpha-ketoglutarate. Defects in this enzyme are linked to carcinogenesis.
Reference: Hassan SA, Gupta V. Maple Syrup Urine Disease. [Updated 2024 Mar 3]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557773/

questions.text: Which of the following is a not a neurotransmitter derived from amino acids
questions.solution:
• Creatine is not a neurotransmitter derived from Amino acids.
  • It is an intermediate product in the formation of Creatinine.


Reference: Harpar’s illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page No 310-311.

questions.text: Nitric oxide is synthesized from which of the following amino acids?
questions.solution:
Nitric oxide is synthesized from the amino acid L-arginine by the enzyme nitric oxide synthase (NOS).

  • NO acts as:

    • Vasodilator → activates guanylyl cyclase → ↑ cGMP.

    • Neurotransmitter in CNS.

    • Immune defense (macrophages).


Other options: 

  • Lysine → Used in collagen synthesis, not NO.

  • Tyrosine → Precursor for dopamine, epinephrine, thyroid hormones.

  • Tryptophan → Precursor for serotonin, melatonin, niacin.

questions.text: Melanin is derived from which of the following amino acids?
questions.solution:
Melanin is synthesized from tyrosine.

Products derived from tyrosine include:
 
  • Melanin
  • Catecholamines (epinephrine, norepinephrine, dopamine)
  • Thyroxine
  • Tyrosine serves as a precursor for melanin, thyroxine, epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA).


Formation of DOPA: Tyrosine is hydroxylated by the enzyme tyrosinase to form dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA). Tyrosinase is a copper-containing monooxygenase.

Formation of melanin: Tyrosinase converts DOPA into dopaquinone, which is further transformed into indolequinone. Indolequinone polymerizes to form melanin.

Formation of catecholamines (epinephrine, norepinephrine, dopamine):

In the adrenal medulla and sympathetic ganglia, tyrosine is hydroxylated to DOPA by tyrosine hydroxylase.
DOPA is decarboxylated to dopamine by DOPA decarboxylase.
Dopamine is then hydroxylated to norepinephrine.
Norepinephrine is methylated by N-methyl transferase (NMT) to form epinephrine, with S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) acting as the methyl donor.

questions.text: A 3year-old child has a history of renal stones, joint pain. On evaluation, you notice he is repeatedly biting his lips and fingers and has lip lacerations, missing sections of his fingers, and developmental delay. Lab reports reveal hyperuricemia. Which enzyme is most likely deficient in this child?
questions.solution: The given clinical scenario of self-mutilating behavior, delayed developmental milestones and hyperuricemia is highly suggestive of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. It occurs due to the complete deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase HGPRT. Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder. Deficiency in HGPRT results in an inability to salvage hypoxanthine or guanine resulting in increased levels of phospho-ribosyl pyrophosphate (PRPP) and decreased levels of inosine monophosphate (IMP) and guanosine monophosphate (GMP). An increase in guanine and hypoxanthine eventually gets converted into uric acid. clinical features include compulsive self-mutilation, intellectual disability, delayed milestones, dystonic movements, and hyperuricemia. The excess uric acid can form kidney stones (urolithiasis) or deposits in joints as urate crystals (gouty arthritis). Ref -Lippincott Illustrated reviews Biochemistry 8th Edition • Page no 329- 330,

questions.text: Diarrhoea,photosensitive skin eruptions and urine analysis showing increased amino acid levels with normal of 5-hydroxyindole acetic acid (5-HIAA) levels is suggestive of which disease.
questions.solution:
Hartnup disease (pellagra-like dermatosis) is an autosomal recessive condition caused due to a single defect in the renal and intestinal transport of neutral amino acids (eg Tryptophan). Decreased intestinal absorption of tryptophan in conjunction with its increased renal loss leads to its reduced bioavailability. This hampers niacin synthesis, and Hartnup disorder can thus present with manifestations of niacin deficiency (pellagra) like diarrhoea, dermatitis and dementia.
Clinical features:
• Most of the children are asymptomatic
• Symptomatic patients show cutaneous photosensitivity
• The skin becomes rough and red after moderate exposure to the sun and with greater exposure, a pellagra-like rash may develop.
• other features include intermittent ataxia , unsteady wide based gait.
Ref: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry 30th Edition • Page nos 308 and 557

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme is deficient in hyperammonemia type 1?
questions.solution:
carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I defect causes hyperammonemia. carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I catalyzes the rate-limiting step in the urea cycle which uses NH and COz as substrates to generate one molecule of carbamoyl phosphate. In the first few days of life, infants with carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I deficiency typically exhibit the effects of hyperammonemia, which may include unusual sleepiness, poorly regulated breathing rate or body temperature, unwillingness to feed, vomiting after feeding, unusual body movements, seizures, or coma.
Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd Edition • Page no 276, 277, 332, 334

questions.text: A neonate presents with lethargy, irritability, poor feeding, seizures and characteristic sweet odor of urine what is the possible diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Maple syrup urine disease (MSUD) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by deficiency of an branched-chain alpha-keto acid dehydrogenase that is required metabolize the three branched-chain amino acids leucine, isoleucine and valine, in the body. The presentation starts with non-specific symptoms of increasing neurological dysfunction and include lethargy, irritability and poor feeding, soon followed by focal neurological signs such as abnormal movements, increasing spasticity, and shortly thereafter, by seizures and deepening coma. If untreated, progressive brain damage is inevitable and death occurs usually within weeks or months.
Patients with MSUD have urine with a characteristic sweet odor, resembling maple syrup.
Phenylketonuria (PKU) is a metabolic disorder resulting from a deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase. Patients with PKU have a musty or mousy odor due to phenylacetic acid accumulation.
Homocystinuria is an inborn error of methionine metabolism caused by a deficiency of the enzyme cystationine β-synthase. It is characterized by tall stature, long limbs, dislocation of the lens of the eye, and predisposition to thromboembolism.
Alkaptonuria is an autosomal recessive disorder of tyrosine metabolism, that develops due to the defect in homogentisate oxidase/homogentisic acid 1, 2 - dioxygenase, which oxidizes homogentisate to maleylacetoacetate. The defect in this enzyme leads to the accumulation of homogentisate, which is then excreted in the urine.
Alkaptonuria is characterized by homogentisic aciduria, ochronosis, and . arthropathy Joint pain).
Homogentisic aciduria is the black discoloration of urine on prolonged exposure to air caused due to oxidation of the excreted homogentisate.Ref- Harpers Biochemistry 31st edition page 286

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids can form oxaloacetate?
questions.solution:
Aspartate is directly converted into oxaloacetate through a transamination reaction catalyzed by aspartate transaminase (AST). In this reaction, the amino group of aspartate is transferred to α-ketoglutarate, forming glutamate and oxaloacetate. Oxaloacetate is a key intermediate of the TCA cycle and can also serve as a substrate for gluconeogenesis, making aspartate a glucogenic amino acid.

Other options:

  • Cysteine: Can be converted to pyruvate, not oxaloacetate.

  • Threonine: Can form succinyl-CoA or acetyl-CoA, not oxaloacetate.

  • Glutamine: Converted to α-ketoglutarate, not oxaloacetate.

This way, only aspartate is the amino acid forming oxaloacetate.





Reference
DM Vasudevan Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students , 10th Edition , Page no. 156

questions.text: A 65-year-old male, with a known history of coronary artery disease, presented for a routine check-up. His vital signs are within normal limits, and he has notably long limbs. Laboratory results show a blood glucose concentration of 100 mg/dL and a homocysteine concentration of 20 pmol/L. His serum lipid levels are normal. Based on this information, which enzyme is most likely deficient in this patient? (Note: Normal homocysteine concentration in blood = 5-15 pmol/L.)
questions.solution:
This patient likely has homocystinuria, based on:

1. Elevated homocysteine (20 pmol/L vs. normal 5–15 pmol/L)
2. Marfanoid habitus (notably long limbs)
3. History of coronary artery disease (homocysteine is thrombogenic and accelerates atherosclerosis)
4. Normal glucose and lipid levels (rules out diabetes/metabolic syndrome)

Cystathionine B synthase enzyme deficiency is the main cause of homocystinuria, which results in the buildup of homocysteine in the blood and urine. Usually normal at birth, the first indication is lens subluxation, or ectopia lentis, which usually manifests after three years of age.


Classical findings:
  1. ↑ Homocysteine in blood and urine
  2. Marfanoid habitus (tall stature, long limbs)
  3. Lens dislocation (downward, vs upward in Marfan's)
  4. Thrombosis (major cause of morbidity/mortality)
  5. Intellectual disability (variable)
  6. Osteoporosis
Other options:
  1. HGPRTase – Deficient in Lesch-Nyhan syndrome (hyperuricemia, self-mutilation, dystonia)
  2. Cystathionine γ-lyase (hydrogenase is incorrect name) – Converts cystathionine to cysteine, not the step where homocysteine accumulates
  3. Homogentisate oxidase – Deficient in alkaptonuria (dark urine, ochronosis, arthropathy)

Reference
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition - Page no 3018

questions.text: Which of the following is considered as a universal methyl group donor in various biochemical reactions?
questions.solution:
Methionine in the form of S-adenosyl methionine is used for various biochemical reactions and is considered the universal methyl group donor.

S-adenosyl methionine is made from methionine and ATP and the reaction is catalyzed by the enzyme methionine adenosyltransferase(MAT) which has 3 isoenzymes. MAT-1 and MAT-3 are seen in the liver whereas MAT-2 is seen in nonhepatic tissues.

Function of S-Adenosyl methionine:
1. Transmethylation reactions:

* Norepinephrine to Epinephrine
* Ethanolamine to Choline
* Acetyl serotonin to Melatonin
* Guanidinoacetate to Creatine

2. DNA methylation

3. Polyamine synthesis:

* Cadaverine
* Putrescine
* Spermidine
* Spermine

Other options: 

  • Acetyl-CoA: Donates acetyl groups, not methyl groups

  • S-Adenosyl Serine: Does not exist; incorrect term

  • Glucose-6-phosphate: Intermediate in glycolysis and pentose phosphate pathway; not involved in methyl group donation


Reference: Harper's illustrated Biochemistry 31st edition page no 298-302

questions.text: A young female comes to the emergency department after ingesting 10 tablets of Phenobarbital. Which of the following components of the ETC is inhibited by this drug?
questions.solution:
• Phenobarbital is a barbiturate that inhibits complex I to Q of the electron transport chain. Complex I of the electron transport chain is NADH-Q oxidoreductase.
  • It oxidizes NADH and reduces coenzyme Q. Phenobarbital inhibits complex I to Q so that the electrons will not be able to be transferred from NADH to coenzyme Q, which is the first step in the electron transport chain.
  • As a result, the rate of oxygen consumption will decrease. The electron transport chain (ETC) represents the final pathway through which electrons, originating from the oxidation of carbohydrates, fatty acids, and amino acids, are channeled toward a final reaction with oxygen to produce water and ATP.
  • The ETC complexes are embedded in the inner mitochondrial membrane.
Reference: Harpar’s illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page No 122-127, 159.

questions.text: A 2-year-old male appears with pellagra-like lesions and urine that contains amino acids. Out of the four siblings in the family, two are experiencing the same symptoms while two siblings, and the parents remain unaffected. The most likely conclusion is:
questions.solution:
Hartnup disease is an autosomal recessive disorder resulting in impaired functioning of transport protein in intestines and kidneys. This results in wasting of neutral amino acids which manifests as pellagra like clinical symptoms.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 298.

questions.text: Pick the incorrect change with respect to cancers
questions.solution:
(1) Methylation of tumor suppressor genes, (2) Hypomethylation of oncogenes, and (3) Loss of heterozygosity  - all are commonly seen in cancer cells. 
Methylation of tumor suppressor genes leads to their underexpression and contributes to carcinogenesis
Hypomethylation of oncogenes leads to overexpression and contributes to proliferative drive in cancer cells.
Loss of heterozygosity too is commonly seen. 

Mutations in introns (4) is incorrect with respect to cancers.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 366.

questions.text: Genetic alterations that do not change the DNA's sequence are referred to as epigenetic changes. The following can all identify epigenetic change, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
HPLC is used in the determination of plasma levels of drugs/metabolites. 
Its also used to separate, identify, and quantify each part of a mixture.
It's not used to identify epigenetic changes.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 25.

questions.text: Which from the list given below does not undergo post-translational modification?
questions.solution:
Selenocysteine is not formed as a result of post-translational modification, but rather is directly introduced through co-translation into a developing polypeptide during translation.

Thus, selenocysteine is often referred to as the "21st amino acid."

But unlike the other 20 amino acids, selenocysteine's incorporation is controlled by a substantial and intricate genetic component for the peculiar tRNA that makes use of the STOP-signaling UGA anticodon.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 18.

questions.text: A DNA's structure is displayed below. What ties two nitrogenous bases together?
questions.solution:
Nitrogenous bases are held together by hydrogen bonds.

Deoxyguanosine nucleotide and deoxycytidine nucleotide are joined by three hydrogen bonds created by hydrogen linked to electronegative N or O atoms, while the A-T pair is joined by two hydrogen links.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 397.

questions.text: What changes in a gene results from RNAi?
questions.solution:
RNA interference (RNAi) is a biological process in which RNA molecules inhibit gene expression or translation by neutralizing targeted mRNA molecules. This process is known as Knock down. 


Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 459.

questions.text: What is the specific site in gene research where CRE recombinase binds?
questions.solution:
The LoxP site is the particular location in gene research where the enzyme CRE recombinase interacts.
 
Fact based Q.

questions.text: What is the phenomena whereby future generations run the danger of manifesting diseases at an earlier and more severe stage?
questions.solution:
Anticipation refers to the situation whereby future generations run the danger of manifesting  diseases at an earlier and more severe stage. It is also known as Sherman's paradox. 

It is commonly seen in trinucleotide repeat disorders such has Huntington's disease- CAG repeats and Myotonic dystrophy-CTG repeats. 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology,10th edition, page no 145.

questions.text: What is ABO blood group inheritance?
questions.solution:
Blood group antigens and histocompatibility are two such examples showing codominant inheritance.

One set is inherited from both maternal and paternal chromosomes each
It is less prone to mutations than human DNA

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct about mitochondrial DNA?
questions.solution:
Mitochondrial DNA is much more likely to accumulate mutations compared to nuclear DNA.
It encodes for 20% of the enzymes found in the respiratory chain and is transmitted solely
via the mother's egg. Its size is smaller than that of the nuclear genome, measuring
16 kilobase pairs. It also has a high mutation rate (5-10 times that of nuclear DNA). 

Hence, amongst the given options - only option (1) is correct.

questions.text: In a surgical intensive care unit, restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) was used to identify five different staphylococci species. In which of the following situations do restriction enzymes act?
questions.solution:
Restriction enzymes recognize palindromic sequences. In this case, “GATTAC” on one strand is complemented by “CATTAG” on the opposite strand, forming a palindromic sequence that is recognized and cut by certain restriction enzymes.

Reference: Lippincott' Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 465.

questions.text: Which one of the following is a gene editing tool?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: CRISPR

Genome editing tool derived from bacteria.
Consists of
  • A guide RNA (gRNA) which is complementary to target DNA sequence
  • Endonuclease (Cas9) which makes either single or double stranded break at the target site.
The resultant break either gets
  • Imperfectly repaired by non-homologous end joining or

questions.text: Northern blot detects?

questions.text: Which is a biomarker of alcoholic hepatitis?
questions.solution:
In alcoholic hepatitis, AST is typically elevated and often shows a higher level compared to ALT (Alanine Aminotransferase), usually with an AST/ALT ratio greater than 2:1.
This ratio is a hallmark of alcoholic liver disease.
 

While GGT (gamma-glutamyl transferase) and ALP (alkaline phosphatase) can also be elevated in liver disease, AST is the more specific biomarker for alcoholic liver injury.
LDH (lactate dehydrogenase) is less specific and can be elevated in various conditions.


Reference: Lippincott' Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 251.

questions.text: DNA is changed in genomic imprinting by:
questions.solution:
Imprinting's biological basis is still not well understood. Gene expression is known to be influenced by DNA methylation, and imprinting is frequently linked to various DNA methylation patterns. Histone H4 deacetylation and methylation are other methods.

Reference: Lippincott' Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 460.

questions.text: DNA estimation is possible using:
questions.solution:
DNA estimation by spectrophotometer is a laboratory technique used to determine the concentration and purity of a DNA sample.

It involves measuring the absorbance of the sample at different wavelengths and then calculating an approximate concentration.

This technique can also be used to assess the amount of contamination in a DNA sample and determine if it is suitable for further analysis.

Other options: -
  • Spirometer- measures lung volumes
  • pH meter- measures pH
  • Sphygmometer- measures BP 

Reference: Lippincott' Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 14.

questions.text: When many codons correspond to the same amino acid, this occurrence is referred to as:
questions.solution:
Degeneracy is a feature of the genetic code where more than one 3-nucleotide sequence (called a codon) can code for the same amino acid in a protein. This is also referred to as synonymous codon usage.

The genetic code contains an inherent redundancy, meaning that multiple codons can be used to represent a single amino acid. This means that even if one codon is mutated, a different codon that codes for the same amino acid can be used instead.

This allows some degree of protection against the deleterious effects of certain single-codon mutations, improving the accuracy and reliability of the translated protein.

Reference: Lippincott' Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 433.

questions.text: Why are CG islands in our DNA important?
questions.solution:
The cytosine nucleotide is followed by a guanine nucleotide at the CpG sites, also known as CG sites, in a linear sequence along the 5' 3' orientation of the DNA molecule.
CpG islands are genomic areas having a high frequency of CpG sites.

CpG dinucleotides' cytosines can be methylated to create 5-methylcytosines. A gene's expression can be altered by this methylation. 

Methylation results in silencing/decreasing the expression of the gene. 

Reference: Lippincott' Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 460.

questions.text: What percentage of the total human genome is made up of coding DNA?
questions.solution:
Coding DNA makes 1-2% of the total DNA in human body. 

Reference: Lippincott' Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 465.

questions.text: What results from cytosine methylation?
questions.solution:
Epigenetic mechanisms involved in cancer include methylation of specific cytosine bases in genes, resulting in silencing of certain genes. Post-translational modifications of histones, such as acetylation, methylation, phosphorylation and ubiquitination also affect gene expression.

remember acetylation - kind of activation and methylation is like deactivation.
Reference: Lippincott' Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 460.

questions.text: What determines the exact placement of a genomic loci?
questions.solution:
Exact location of a genetic loci is identified by Fluorescent in-situ hybridization (FISH).

FISH, which uses fluorescent rather than radioactively labeled probes, is a very sensitive technique for determining the exact location of a genetic loci.

This frequently places the gene on a given band or region of the chromosome.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology,10th edition, Page no 165.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about ribozyme?
questions.solution:
Ribozymes are RNA molecules that can catalyze reactions. Ribozymes are important in the formation of peptide bonds (peptidyl transferase activity).

questions.text: A light microscope can be used to see chromosomes with a resolution of ____?
questions.solution:
Chromosomes are visualized through a light microscope with resolution of 5 mb.

This analysis is called Karyotype analysis.

It helps to detect both numerical and structural chromosomal aberrations.

Overall resolution in this procedure is 5 Mega bases (mb).

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology,10th edition, Page no 164.

questions.text: What is the objective of a real-time polymerase chain reaction?
questions.solution:
Real time polymerase chain reaction is done for monitoring amplification of target nucleic acid.

A quantitative polymerase chain reaction (qPCR), also known as real-time polymerase chain reaction, is a molecular biology laboratory technique that uses the polymerase chain reaction (PCR) to amplify and simultaneously quantify the targeted DNA molecule.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 66.

questions.text: How does one identify the exact location of a genetic loci is?
questions.solution:
Amongst the given options - Fluorescent in-situ hybridization (FISH) can help in identifying the exact location of genetic loci.

Fluorescent in-situ hybridization (FISH) is a molecular cytogenetic technique that is used to detect and locate the presence or absence of specific DNA sequences on chromosomes. It uses fluorescent probes that attach to very specific regions of DNA, allowing for the visualization of the exact location or loci of specific genes on a chromosome.

FISH can be used to detect genetic rearrangements associated with diseases, chromosomal abnormalities, and even the presence of specific genes in a sample. 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology,10th edition, Page no 165.

questions.text: For which of these is real time polymerase chain reaction done?
questions.solution:
A real-time polymerase chain reaction (real-time PCR, or qPCR) is a laboratory technique of molecular biology based on the polymerase chain reaction (PCR). It monitors the amplification of a targeted DNA molecule during the PCR (i.e., in real time), not at its end, as in conventional PCR. 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 66.

questions.text: What does the division of a chromosome perpendicular to the normal axis of division lead to?
questions.solution:
Isochromosomes show loss of one arm with duplication of other due to perpendicular rather than horizonta separation of chromosomes. 

Most common isochromosome encountered is 2 q arms of X chromosome which is seen in ~ 15% patients of Turner's syndrome. 



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology,10th edition, Page no 166.

questions.text: Which of these is absent from the Klenow fragment's activity?
questions.solution:
The Klenow fragment of DNA polymerase is used for random primer labelling because it lacks a 5'-> 3' exonuclease activity. This is prepared by cleavage of DNA polymerase with subtilisin, giving a large enzyme fragment which has no 5' - 3' exonuclease activity, but still acts as 5'- 3 'polymerase.

questions.text: Which of the following methods has RNA as its foundation?
questions.solution:
PCR facilitates the expansion and study of DNA extracted from single cells, hair follicles, or spermatozoa and thus has plenty of utilization in forensic medicine. Apart from that, it is also used to detect hidden viruses, diagnose fetal genetic issues, identify gene polymorphisms, confirm tissue types of transplants and analyze the evolution via retroviral reverse transcriptase-derived c DNA copies of mRNA (RT-PCR method).

questions.text: What one of the following is not required to have a 5' capping?
questions.solution:
Capping is a process which protects 5' end of mRNA and polyadenylation protects 3' end against the action of exonucleases. 

mRNA, snRNA and siRNA undergo this process but tRNA and rRNA are relatively stable. Hence, they do not undergo capping at the 5' end. 

Reference: Lippincott' Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 425.

questions.text: What alteration of the cytosine residues at CpG islands in DNA does not favour permissive euchromatin?
questions.solution:
Methylation causes inactivation of DNA and inhibits the formation of transcriptionally active euchromatin. 

It is an example of epigenetic modification. Examples include

1. Methylation of cytosine residues in CpG islands
2. Modification of histones by acetylation or methylation
3. Changes in high order chromatin structure. 

Reference: Lippincott' Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 460.

questions.text: What is the phenomenon shown below?
questions.solution:
Complementation is a process in genetics where two strains of an organism with different homozygous recessive mutations that produce the same mutant phenotype, such as a change in wing structure in flies, are mated or crossed and the offspring has a wild-type phenotype. The blue-white assay is a technique used to screen for and detect gene uptake during genetic engineering based on the principle of alpha-complementation of the beta-galactosidase gene. A defective galactosidase gene product activity is complemented by a similarly defective gene product from a plasmid, which together become active. This can be used to determine a successful gene uptake as it disrupts the plasmid gene product and complementation cannot occur, resulting in white colonies and an unsuccessful gene insertion will result in blue colonies.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 445.

questions.text: What is the best investigation for metabolic disorders?
questions.solution:
Tandem mass spectrometry can be used to screen blood samples from newborns for the presence and concentrations of amino acids, fatty acids, and other metabolites.

Abnormalities in metabolite levels can serve as diagnostic indicators for a variety of genetic disorders, such as phenylketonuria, ethylmalonic encephalopathy, and glutaric acidemia type 1.

Reference: Lippincott' Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 270.

questions.text: Which enzyme deficiency results in Lesch-Nyhan syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT)

Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome is an X linked recessive disorder which occurs due to deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine guanine phosphoribosyl transferase ( HGPRT )
HGPRT is responsible for generation of purine nucleotides such as IMP/GMP from bases such as hypoxanthine/guanine via purine salvage pathway.
As a result, purines accumulate resulting in increased degradation and generation of uric acid leading to hyperuricemia.

Clinically manifests as-
  • Self mutilation
  • Aggression
  • Intellectual disability
  • Hyperuricemia
  • Gout
Remember- Partial deficiency of HGPRTase results in Kelley-Seegmiller syndrome.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 301.

questions.text: Regarding DNA polymerase III, which of these is accurate?
questions.solution:
In prokaryotic DNA polymerase, DNA replication is a function of DNA polymerase 3.

questions.text: What do chaperones help with?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Protein Folding

Chaperons are a type of heat shock protein which assist in protein folding.
Mechanism of Action
  • Bind to short sequences of hydrophobic amino acids of extended polypeptide.
  • Thereby, they effectively shield the new polypeptide being synthesized from aggregating providing them with an opportunity to form an appropriate secondary structure.
Improper functioning of chaperons results in protein misfolding diseases such as
  • Prion disease: Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease and bovine spongiform encephalopathy.

  • Beta thalassemia

questions.text: Which of the following methods is used to find variations in gene expression and DNA sequence?
questions.solution:
Answer, option 4:- Microarray

- **Microarray** is a technique used to analyze and compare gene expression levels and variations in DNA sequences across thousands of genes simultaneously. It is commonly used to detect changes in mRNA expression (gene expression profiling) and identify mutations or single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in DNA.  

### Other Options:
1. **Northern Blot**: Used to detect RNA (mRNA) levels of a specific gene, indicating its expression.  
2. **Southern Blot**: Used to detect specific DNA sequences in a sample.  
3. **Western Blot**: Used to detect specific proteins in a sample.

questions.text: Gout is a disorder associated with:

Divided into primary and secondary gout.

Biochemical defect is increased activity of the enzymes PRPP synthase and PRPP glutamylamidotransferase  which results in increased synthesis of purines and thereby increased breakdown.

questions.text: Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is caused by which enzyme deficiency?

Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome is an X linked recessive disorder which occurs due to deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine guanine phosphoribosyl transferase ( HGPRT )
HGPRT is responsible for generation of purine nucleotides such as IMP/GMP from bases such as hypoxanthine/guanine via purine salvage pathway.
As a result, purines accumulate resulting in increased degradation and generation of uric acid leading to hyperuricemia.

Clinically manifests as-
  • Self mutilation

questions.text: Which of the following methods is used to repair DNA in CRISPR-CAS 9?
questions.solution:
The primary method of gene repair by CRISPR-Cas9 is non homologous end joining (NHEJ) repair.

CRISPR  stands for Clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats.

The genome-editing technique CRISPR-Cas-9 allows specific bacteria to access genetic material.

The transcription of CRISPRs results in an RNA sequence that directs Cas-9 to a sequence that causes cleavage.

An artificial guide-RNA used in gene editing binds to Cas-9 and is complementary to the DNA sequence of interest. Double-stranded DNA breaks, also known as Double-Stranded Breaks (DSBs), are brought about by Cas9.

Then, NHEJ repair and homologous repair are used to repair DCBs. The more important of the two pathways is NHEJ repair because eukaryotes have a relatively poor homologous repair efficiency.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 413.

questions.text: The binding of mRNA with ribosomes in eukaryotes is guided by which of the following ?
questions.solution:
mRNA has poly-A tails at the 3' end and a 7-methylguanosine cap at the 5' end.
The ribosome is able to identify the site of attachment to the mRNA with the help of the 7-methylguanosine caps.
Following the ribosome's binding to the 5' end, it scans downstream until it comes across an AUG Codon (Start codon)
The polyadenylation sequence (Poly A tail), which is located at the 3' end, helps stabilise the mRNA, facilitates its escape from the nucleus, and aids in translation.
The length of the poly-A tails steadily shortens as the mRNA moves into the cytosol.
The tRNA molecule functions as adaptors for the conversion of the information contained in the mRNA's nucleotide sequence into particular amino acids.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 457.

questions.text: Which of the following techniques makes use of RNA
questions.solution:
A laboratory method called reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) combines Reverse transcription of RNA into DNA and target-specific DNA amplification. It is mostly employed to calculate the quantity of a specific RNA. Southern blot method is used to identify a specific DNA segment throughout the entire genome. The northern blot technique is used to show specific RNA. A technique for DNA sequencing called Sanger sequencing relies on the selective incorporation of chain-terminating dideoxynucleotides by DNA polymerase during in vitro DNA replication.

questions.text: Which of the following is caused by RNAi in a gene?
questions.solution:
Gene knockdown- is an experimental method that lowers the expression of one or more genes in an organism. A short DNA or RNA oligonucleotide having a sequence corresponding to either a gene or an mRNA transcript can be used , or genetic modification can also result in the reduction.
Gene knockout, is a genetic technique that renders one of an organism's genes inoperative. ("knocked out" of the organism).

KO can also refer to the organism that possesses a gene knockout or the gene that has been deleted
Gene knockin- A genetic engineering technique known as a gene knock-in (abbreviation: KI) in molecular cloning and biology involves the one-for-one replacement of DNA sequence information in a genetic locus or the insertion of sequence information not present in the locus.

Gene knock up- upregulate the levels of a given protein while retaining its cell-type-specific regulation.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 459.

questions.text: Which of the following mRNA regions does miRNA attach to?
questions.solution:
Short non-coding RNAs called miRNAs (microRNAs) regulate post-transcriptional gene expression. They typically bind to the 3'-UTR (untranslated region) of their target mRNAs and suppress the synthesis of proteins by destabilizing the mRNA and silencing translation. 

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 459.

questions.text: Mention the % of Cytosine if the % of thymine residues in DNA is 28%.
questions.solution:
Chargaff's rule is important for understanding DNA structure, as it explains the relative amounts of the four major bases in DNA molecules. The ratio of purine to pyrimidine bases in the DNA molecule is always around 1, meaning that the number of guanine and adenine molecules will be around the same, while the ratio of thymine to cytosine molecules will also be around to 1. This is important for complementary base pairing, as the A and T bases will always be equal, as will the G and C bases. This allows the double stranded DNA molecule to form its characteristic double helix structure, with complementary base pairs fitting neatly together. The shape of the double helix is maintained by the different widths of the two grooves that surround it, referred to as the major and minor grooves, with the major groove providing easier access to the DNA sequence in the helix.

Applying this rule, if thymine is 28%, adenine is also 28%.

Therefore concentration of guanine and cytosine together = 100 - (2 × 28) = 44.

Since, guanine and cytosine concentrations are equal, G=C= 44/2= 22%.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 397.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct order of steps in  polymerase chain reaction (PCR)?
questions.solution:
The process of polymerase chain reaction involves Denaturation, Annealing, Extension

A. Denaturation - Separation of DNA by melting through 94 C for 3 minutes.
- Converts double stranded DNA to single stranded DNA

B. Annealing - Hybridization of two oligonucleotides used as primers to the target DNA to form template-primer hybridization complex. 
-At 3’end at 54C for 45seconds

C. Extension - Elongation of DNA chain by nucleotide addition from the primers
- Using DNA polymerase as catalyst in the presence of Mg2+ ions - At 72 C for 2 mins

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 452.

questions.text: Identify the hair abnormalities using polarising light microscopy?
questions.solution:

Trichothiodystrophy:
Autosomal recessive disorder
Due to defect in DNA repair
Defective DNA Nucleotide Excision Repair (NER)

questions.text:
Alternate splicing occurs in a gene with segments 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 and a primer with the letters w, x, y, and z. It produces two goods, A and B.
Which primers are used to yield product A?
questions.solution:
Product A includes segment 1,3,4 and 5 in its structure.

Seg 1- Needs to be transcribed, so W is essential
Seg 2- Doesn't need to be transcribed
Seg 3- Needs to be transcribed, so Y is essential
Seg 4- Requires promotor Z but not essential since promotor Y can continue the transcription as indicated by the arrow.

questions.text: What is explained by the genetic code's wobble theory?

There are 61 codons that synthesis amino acids,therefore, there must be 61 tRNAs each having different anticodons. But the total number of tRNAs is less than 61.

questions.text:

questions.text: What kind of defect is found in HNPCC?
questions.solution:
DNA mismatch repair (MMR) gene mutations in the germline are the primary cause of the prevalent inherited form of neoplasia known as hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC). Human exonuclease 1 is one of the proteins that MMR proteins have been shown to bind with (hEXO1).

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 380.

questions.text: Where is a mismatch repair defect seen?
questions.solution:
DNA mismatch repair (MMR) gene mutations in the germline are the primary cause of the prevalent inherited form of neoplasia known as hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC). Human exonuclease 1 is one of the proteins that MMR proteins have been shown to bind with (hEXO1).

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 380.

questions.text: Methylation of DNA has nothing to do with:
questions.solution:
DNA Methylation is not related with capping.

Capping refers to the addition of a 7-methylguanylate cap to the 5' end of eukaryotic mRNA and is involved in RNA processing, stability, and translation initiation.

DNA Methylation plays a very important role in a number of key processes including
  • genomic imprinting
  • X-chromosome inactivation
  • Suppression of repetitive element transcription and transposition
  • when dysregulated, contributes to diseases like cancer
  • mismatch repair
  • chromatin remodelling
Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 698.

questions.text: Correct way to estimate viral load is:
questions.solution:
Viral load can be estimated by RT PCR.

This is done by taking a sample of known viral concentration (available commercially) and running a series of 10x dilutions on the same protocol and recording the resulted CT (cycle threshold) with each known level of viral load for that specific test, run in that particular way.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 453.

questions.text: How many different amino acids may possibly be coded by such a system, if  a 4 nucleotides sequence code for an amino acid instead of 3?
questions.solution:
If there would have been two nucleotides in each codon, the chance of their varied combination will be 4 raised to the power 2, i.e. 16, and three nucleotide in each codon means there will occur 4 raised to the power 3 , i.e. 64 codons are possible. According to the above calculation, if there occurs 4 nucleotides in a codon, tire chance of their varied combination will be 4 raised to power 4, i.e. 256.


Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 16.

questions.text: Why are there multiple codons for the same amino acid?
questions.solution:
Degeneracy is the redundancy of the genetic code, where more than one triplet codes one amino acid. Degeneracy means the coding of a particular amino acid by more than one codon. Since numerous distinct codons define the same amino acid, the genetic code degenerates. This allows for greater permutations and combinations to code for a particular amino acid.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 405.

questions.text: Which of the following polypeptides is produced by the translation of the m-RNA poly (A) tail?
questions.solution:
Poly A tail is translated into the polylysine tail as AAA is the codon for lysine amino acid. The poly-A tail makes the RNA molecule more stable and prevents its degradation. Additionally, the poly-A tail allows the mature messenger RNA molecule to be exported from the nucleus and translated into a protein by ribosomes in the cytoplasm.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 412.

questions.text: What is CAP in LAC operon an example of?
questions.solution:
CAP in LAC operon is an example of positive regulator. CAP-cAMP regulator is a positive regulator for Lac operon because its presence is required for gene expression. Operon = structural genes coding for enzymes of metabolic pathway + regulatory genes that determine their transcription.

questions.text: In a polymerase chain reaction, which of the following is not used?
questions.solution:
Dideoxyribonucleotides are not used in polymerase chain reaction. The key ingredients of a PCR reaction are Taq polymerase, primers, template DNA, and nucleotides (DNA building blocks).

Dideoxyribonucleotides are used in Sanger's sequencing.

questions.text: Which of the following does not have a role in eukaryotes' ability to synthesise proteins?

Ribosomes, Peptidyl transferase, and aminoacyl t -RNA synthetase - all are involved in the process of Translation(synthesis of proteins from RNA).

questions.text: All of the following, with the exception of ______________ can be used to detect chromosomal mutations.
questions.solution:
Denaturing gradient gel electrophoresis (DGGE) is a technique used to detect mutations or variations in DNA sequences. It separates double-stranded DNA molecules based on their melting behavior, which is dependent on their nucleotide sequence. This technique is particularly useful in detecting point mutations, deletions, and insertions in PCR-amplified DNA fragments.
On the other hand, Single strand conformational polymorphism (SSCP), Dideoxynucleotide trial sequencing, and Agarose gel electrophoresis are also methods used to detect chromosomal mutations.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 68.

questions.text: Test to differentiate the chromosome of normal and cancer cells:

The entire DNA specimen from the sample of interest is labeled in one color and the normal control DNA specimen is indicated by another color. questions.text: Pyrimidine nucleotides are synthesized in salvage pathway of Pyrimidine synthesis through:
questions.solution:
Correct option 3:Both pyrimidine bases and nucleosides 
  • Pyrimidine nucleotides are synthesized through the salvage pathway of pyrimidine synthesis via both pyrimidine bases and nucleosides.
  • The salvage pathway is an important pathway for the synthesis of nucleotides, as it allows the reuse of nucleobases and nucleosides that are generated during the degradation of RNA and DNA.
  • In the salvage pathway, the free pyrimidine bases and nucleosides are converted into the corresponding nucleotides through the addition of a phosphate group, which is derived from ATP.
  • The enzymes involved in the salvage pathway are specific for pyrimidine bases and nucleosides, and they differ from those involved in de novo pyrimidine synthesis.
  • This pathway is energetically favorable, as it requires less ATP than the de novo pathway.
Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 342.

questions.text: The template DNA strand has the following sequence: 5'-GATATC -3'. What RNA sequence will be produced?
questions.solution:
The correct option is 2.
  • The RNA sequence produced from the given DNA template strand is 5'-GAUAUC-3'.
  • This is because RNA is synthesized by complementary base pairing with the template DNA strand, using the rules of base pairing (A with U and G with C).
  • So, for the given DNA sequence 5'-GATATC-3', the RNA sequence produced would be 5'-GAUAUC-3', where T in DNA is replaced by U in RNA. 
Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 349.

questions.text: Which of the following approaches is best for evaluating a gene's function?
questions.solution:
Option 4, Transgenic animals, is the best approach for evaluating a gene's function.
  • Transgenic animals are genetically modified organisms that have a foreign gene inserted into their genome. This gene can be specifically chosen to study the function of a particular gene or protein.
  • By creating transgenic animals, researchers can study the effects of overexpressing or under expressing a gene, as well as the effects of mutations or deletions in the gene.
  • Transgenic animals are particularly useful for studying the function of genes in vivo, which means in a living organism.
  • This approach allows researchers to study the effects of gene expression in the context of a whole organism, rather than just in isolated cells or tissues.
  • In contrast, Southern blot and Northern blot are molecular biology techniques used to detect the presence and expression of specific DNA or RNA sequences, respectively. These techniques are useful for detecting the presence or absence of a particular gene or transcript, but they do not provide information about the gene's function.
  • Gene knockout animals, on the other hand, are animals that have had a specific gene intentionally deleted from their genome.
  • These animals are useful for studying the effects of the loss of a particular gene, but they do not allow researchers to study the effects of overexpression or mutations in the gene. 
Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 454.

questions.text: Which of the following explains the principle of X-Inactivation?
questions.solution:

questions.text: A young male with a H/O dyslipidemia having ABCA-1 mutation shows the following see the image and tell diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Enlarged and yellowish/ Orange tonsils are pathognomonic of Tangier's disease.
 

Tangier disease is a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the ABCA1 gene. The ABCA1 protein is critical for the transport of cholesterol and phospholipids to apolipoprotein A-I (ApoA-I), which is essential for the formation of high-density lipoprotein (HDL).

Key features of Tangier disease:

  • Extremely low or absent HDL cholesterol levels ("hypoalphalipoproteinemia").
  • Accumulation of cholesterol in various tissues, leading to enlarged, orange-colored tonsils, hepatosplenomegaly, and peripheral neuropathy.
  • Increased risk of atherosclerosis despite low levels of circulating cholesterol.



Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st edition, Page no 258.

questions.text: Dideoxy Nucleotide Triphosphate (dd NTP's) in Sanger's sequencing technique are used for?
questions.solution:
• Dideoxy nucleotide triphosphates (ddNTPs) are used in Sanger sequencing to terminate DNA polymerization.
  • Sanger sequencing is a method for determining the nucleotide sequence of a DNA fragment. In this method, DNA is synthesized in vitro using a DNA template, a DNA polymerase enzyme, and a mixture of deoxyribonucleotide triphosphates (dNTPs), which are the building blocks of DNA.
  • In addition to the dNTPs, the reaction mixture also contains a small amount of one of four different ddNTPs, each labeled with a different fluorescent dye. These ddNTPs lack a hydroxyl group on the 3' carbon of the sugar, which prevents further nucleotide addition after they are incorporated into the growing DNA chain.
  • As a result, the polymerase enzyme randomly incorporates the ddNTPs into the newly synthesized DNA chain, leading to the termination of the chain elongation at different positions.
  • The resulting mixture of DNA fragments of different lengths, terminated at different positions, can then be separated by size using gel electrophoresis, and the sequence can be determined based on the order of the labeled ddNTPs that are detected using a fluorescence scanner.

Reference : Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 31st edition , Page no 26,27,439 .

questions.text: DNA - protein interaction can be studied by using?
questions.solution:
• DNA-protein interactions can be studied by several methods, but one of the most effective ways is through DNAse footprinting.
  • In this technique, a protein is allowed to bind to DNA, and then the complex is treated with DNAse, an enzyme that cleaves DNA at random locations.
  • However, the enzyme cannot cleave the DNA when it is bound to the protein, creating a region of protected DNA. This region is called a "footprint," and it reveals the specific sequence where the protein is bound to the DNA.
  • The DNA fragments are then separated by gel electrophoresis and visualized to determine the location of the protein-DNA complex.

Reference : Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 31st edition , Page no 341,445,451 .

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding Human Genome Project?
questions.solution:
The false statement regarding the Human Genome Project is: Took 2 years to complete

The Human Genome Project was a large-scale international research project that aimed to sequence and map the entire human genome. It was a long-term endeavor that spanned over a decade, not just two years. The project officially began in 1990 and was completed in 2003, taking a total of approximately 13 years to finish.

To summarize the correct statements:

  • Collaboration of many countries: True. The Human Genome Project involved the collaboration of multiple countries around the world, including the United States, the United Kingdom, France, Germany, Japan, and others.
  • Around 20,000 genes were identified & sequenced: As part of the project, scientists identified and sequenced approximately 20,000-25,000 protein-coding genes within the human genome.
  • Used modern sequencing techniques: The Human Genome Project utilized modern sequencing techniques and technologies, such as automated DNA sequencing, to decipher the sequence of base pairs in the human genome.
  

Reference : Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 31st edition , Page no 3, 701 .

questions.text: Differential expression of genetic material is seen in?
questions.solution:
The differential expression of genetic material is observed in Genomic Imprinting (option 2)

Genomic Imprinting 

  • Genomic imprinting refers to an epigenetic phenomenon where specific genes are expressed in a parent-of-origin-dependent manner.
  • This means that certain genes are expressed differently depending on whether they are inherited from the mother or the father. In genomic imprinting, one copy of the gene is typically "imprinted" or marked during gamete formation, resulting in gene expression being restricted to either the paternal or maternal allele.

Diseases involving Genomic imprinting include

  • Prader-Willi syndrome: Intellectual disability, obesity, and behavioral problems. Caused by a loss of function of genes on the paternal chromosome 15. ( P for Prader, P for paternal)
  • Angelman syndrome:  intellectual disability, developmental delays, and seizures(Happy Puppet). Caused by a loss of function of genes on the maternal chromosome 15. (A for Angelman, A for amma(mother) 
  • Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome:  Rapid growth, hemihypertrophy, abdominal wall defects and an increased risk of Wilm/RMS/Gonadoblastoma etc. Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is caused by an overgrowth of cells in the placenta during pregnancy. This can lead to an increase in the number of copies of imprinted genes on the short arm of chromosome 11.(WT2)
 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 144,175,178,179,180,1285.
