questions.text: The coding sequence present in the RNA molecule is CAAGGU. What will be the sequence in the DNA template strand?
questions.solution:
The given RNA sequence is CAAGGU. To determine the DNA sequence from which it was transcribed-

Replace RNA bases with their complementary DNA bases:

• C (Cytosine) pairs with G (Guanine)

• A (Adenine) pairs with T (Thymine)

• G (Guanine) pairs with C (Cytosine)

• U (Uracil in RNA) pairs with A (Adenine in DNA)

 Find the DNA template strand (complementary to RNA):

• RNA: CAAGGU

• DNA (template strand): GTTCCA

 Determine the DNA coding strand (same as RNA but with T instead of U):

• DNA (coding strand): CAAGGT

Hence the DNA template strand is GTTC﻿CA, and the DNA coding strand is CAAGGT.

questions.text: Which type of mutation results in the reversal to wild type of phenotype when the mutant gene is suppressed?
questions.solution:
• Mutations in tRNA are known to suppress the mutant gene and cause reversal to wild phenotype. Such mutations are called suppressor mutations
  • Suppressor mutations are secondary mutations that alter the phenotypes caused by an existing mutation. suppressor mutations return the phenotype caused by the original mutation to a more wild-type phenotype despite the presence of the original mutation.
  • The suppressor mutation's effect on the phenotype can vary from partial restoration to full restoration of the wild-type phenotype.
Reference: Harpar’s illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page No 409-410.

questions.text: The template DNA strand is 5‘CATTCAATATCGATC3‘.The resulting mRNA sequence after transcription is
questions.solution:
The mRNA sequence produced from this template DNA fragment will be 5'GAUCGAUAUUGAAUG3'.

The non-template strand, also known as the coding strand or sense/plus strand, will have the same sequence as the RNA produced, except that thymine (T) in the DNA is replaced by uracil (U) in RNA.

Since all sequences are typically written in the 5' to 3' direction unless specified otherwise, the RNA sequence GAUCGAUAUUGAAUG corresponds to the DNA sequence CATTCAATATCGATC on the non-template strand. Both the RNA and the non-template strand are complementary to the template strand.


 

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 349,354 .

questions.text:
Which of the following methods can detect the alterations in DNA sequence?
A. Restriction fragment length analysis
B. Flow cytometry
C. Pyrosequencing
D. FISH
questions.solution:
Alterations in DNA sequences can be detected through restriction fragment length analysis and pyrosequencing.

Restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP), also known as the cleaved amplified polymorphic sequence (CAPS) assay, is a technique used to distinguish organisms based on variations in their DNA sequences. It involves cutting a specific region of DNA with known variability using restriction enzymes, followed by separating the resulting DNA fragments via agarose gel electrophoresis. The number and relative sizes of the fragments are then determined.

Pyrosequencing is a DNA sequencing method based on the synthesis approach. It uses four enzymatic reactions in a single tube to track DNA synthesis. As nucleotides are added to the reaction, pyrophosphate (PPi) is released. This PPi initiates a series of reactions that produce light, with the amount of light being proportional to the amount of DNA and the number of nucleotides incorporated. The light generated is detected and recorded as a peak signal by a detection system, reflecting the activity of all four enzymes involved in the reaction.

 

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st edition, Page no 64,65,441 .

questions.text:
Arrange the following steps of Karyotyping in the correct order :
A. Collect cells by peripheral vein using a heparin syringe.
B. Culture in phytohaemoagglutinin.
C. Incubation at 37 degrees C for 3 days.
D. Harvest with colchicine.
E. Routine staining with Giemsa
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of steps for karyotyping is as follows:

1. Collect cells via a peripheral vein using a heparinized syringe.


2. Culture the cells with phytohemagglutinin.


3. Incubate at 37°C for 3 days.


4. Harvest the cells using colchicine.


5. Perform routine staining with Giemsa.



Karyotyping is a technique used to isolate, stain, and examine chromosomes to identify chromosomal abnormalities. It is applied in prenatal diagnosis, investigating repeated pregnancy loss, diagnosing suspected chromosomal disorders in children and adults, and classifying lymphomas and leukemias for accurate diagnosis, prognosis, and treatment.

Various techniques are employed in karyotyping to study chromosomes. Different staining methods yield various results and enhance our understanding of the chromosomes. Common techniques include:

Q-banding: Fluorescence staining with quinacrine mustard

G-banding: Giemsa staining following partial denaturation of chromatin

R-banding: Reverse Giemsa staining, where light and dark bands are inverted

C-banding: Staining of heterochromatin with silver salts

T-banding: Staining of chromosome telomeres

 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 164-165 .

questions.text: In the liver, the Apo-B gene is completely translated to ApoB-100 and in the intestine, it is translated to Apo8-48 Which of the following mechanism explains this?
questions.solution:
The synthesis of apolipoprotein (ApoB-48) in the intestine and ApoB-100 in the liver is a result of RNA editing occurring in the intestine.

RNA editing is a post-transcriptional modification process where the coding sequence of mRNA is altered before translation, leading to a discrepancy between the mRNA template and the DNA from which it was transcribed. This modification can result in the formation of different proteins and typically involves the insertion of additional uracils at the 3' end of the mRNA, progressing in the 3' to 5' direction.

Specifically, in apolipoprotein B synthesis:

In the liver, the apoB gene is transcribed into mRNA, which is then translated into ApoB-100.

In the intestine, the same apoB gene is transcribed into the same mRNA, but this mRNA undergoes editing by the enzyme cytidine deaminase. This enzyme converts the CAA codon in the mRNA to UAA, creating a stop codon at a specific site. This change transforms a sense codon into a nonsense codon via post-transcriptional deamination of cytosine to uracil. As a result, this edited mRNA translates to ApoB-48.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presented with yellowish discoloration of his skin and sclera. He is otherwise normal. He gives a history of viral infection 10 days ago which resolved 2 days back. He also gives a history of similar episodes in the past following any illness. Lab values are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? Serum bilirubin: 2.4 mg/dl. Unconjugated bilirubin: 2.1mg/dl. Conjugated bilirubin: 0.3mg/dL Serum AST and ALT: Normal
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette presented suggests a diagnosis of Gilbert syndrome.

In this case, the patient's mild jaundice, which occurs only during periods of stress, along with elevated levels of unconjugated bilirubin and normal AST and ALT levels, strongly indicates Gilbert syndrome.

Gilbert syndrome is a benign, familial condition inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. It is characterized by mild, intermittent jaundice typically triggered by stress, illness, or other precipitating factors. Notably, there is no evidence of hemolysis or underlying liver disease. The syndrome is associated with a mutation in the promoter region of the UGT1A1 gene, which leads to a modest decrease in the production of UDP-Glucuronyltransferase, an enzyme essential for the conjugation of bilirubin.

Common precipitating factors for jaundice in Gilbert syndrome include:

Dehydration
Fasting
Menstrual periods
Illness
Vigorous exercise

questions.text: Identify the given inheritance pattern in the given image
questions.solution:
The inheritance pattern shown above is mitochondrial inheritance.
Features of mitochondrial inheritance. (1) inherited from the mother.
(2) caused by mutations in the mitochondrial gene.
(3) Both male and female children born to an affected mother will inherit the disease.
Examples of mitochondrial disease include: Mitochondrial encephalopathy, Lactic acidosis and Stroke like episodes (MELAS) . Ref -Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics 20th Edition • Page nos 600 and 601

questions.text:
Match the following genetic diseases with their respective repeat expansion disorders.
Genetic disease Repeat expansion disorder
(1) Huntington’s disease (a) CGG
(2) Frontotemporal dementia (b) GAA
(3)  Freidreich ataxia (c ) CAG
(4)  Fragile X syndrome (d) GGGGCC
questions.solution:
Genetic disease Repeat expansion disorder Clinical features
(1)Huntington’s disease (a)CAG Choreoathetosis, cognitive and affective dysfunction
(2)Frontotemporal dementia (b)GGGGCC early personality changes (frontal lobe involvement) and loss of social restraints initially, followed by memory loss.
(3)Freidreich ataxia (c )GAA Progressive ataxia, dysarthria, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
(4)Fragile X syndrome (d)CGG Mental retardation, large ears, and jaws, macroorchidism in males

Ref- Harpers illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page 368

questions.text: DNA is present in?
questions.solution:
Mitochondria differ from other cellular structures in that they contain DNA.
It contains circular DNA, known as mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) and encodes a small number of genes - mainly the proteins required for Electron Transport Chain. This DNA is inherited only from mothers because it is the ovum that provides cytoplasm and other cell organelles to the zygote.


Other options: 
1. lysosomes contain the enzymes needed to break down unwanted substances and waste products in cells
2. cytoplasm- region of a cell that envelops the organelles and nucleus
3. endoplasmic reticulum is a sophisticated membrane network that is used for calcium storage, lipid metabolism, and protein production


Reference
Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10e - Page 171 and172

questions.text: Identify the mode of inheritance from the pedigree chart given below.
questions.solution:
Tricks to solve pedigree charts:
1. If all generations are not affected- Recessive
a. both generations affected = Autosomal Recessive
b. only men affected = X linked Recessive
2. If all generations affected- Dominant
a. Dad transmitting to All daughter & no dad to son transmission- X linked Dominant
b. otherwise its Autosomal Dominant
3. Affected mother has 100% affected children

Applying the above rules: this is an autosomal dominant mode of inheritance displayed in the pedigree chart.

Reference
Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10e - page no: 144

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child is being assessed at a primary health center and is noted to have deformed lips from constant biting, an inability to walk, as well as dystonia, spasticity, and choreoathetosis. He has been diagnosed with a deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase. Which disorder is this patient most likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
This 2-year-old male presents with:
  1. Self-mutilation (biting lips and fingers)
  2. Neurological symptoms: dystonia, spasticity, choreoathetosis
  3. Delayed motor development (inability to walk)
  4. Enzyme deficiency: Hypoxanthine-Guanine Phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT)

These findings are classic for Lesch–Nyhan Syndrome, an X-linked recessive disorder.

Pathophysiology
  • HGPRT is involved in purine salvage: converts hypoxanthine and guanine to IMP and GMP
  • Deficiency causes buildup of uric acid due to increased purine degradation
  • Leads to hyperuricemia, neurological dysfunction, and behavioral abnormalities

Other options:
  1. Kelley-Seegmiller syndrome – Partial HGPRT deficiency; presents with gout and hyperuricemia, but no neuro or self-mutilation
  2. Orotic aciduria type I – Deficiency of UMP synthase; presents with megaloblastic anemia unresponsive to B12/folate
  3. Orotic aciduria type II – Same pathway, but with orotate phosphoribosyltransferase deficiency — also shows anemia, not self-mutilation


Reference
1.Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd Edition - Pg no. 344
2. Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th Edition - 2999, 3001, 3002

questions.text: A patient with diarrhea is diagnosed with cholera. The causative agent acts on which of the following receptors?
questions.solution:
Vibrio cholerae, which causes cholera, produces enterotoxin that primarily targets GM1 ganglioside receptors.
Cholera toxin (CT), which has one A subunit and five B subunits. The GM1 ganglioside receptors are bound by the B subunits.



Vibrio cholerae:
  1. gram-negative
  2. comma-shaped bacillus
  3. solitary polar flagellum
  4. darting motility

It is the cause of cholera, an acute diarrheal disease that can cause severe vomiting and abundant, painless diarrhea with flecks of mucus (often referred to as "rice water stools"). This can lead to arrhythmias and pulmonary edema as complications.
The most common way that an infection spreads is by eating or drinking contaminated food or water.

Reference:
Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, Tenth Edition, Pages 309, 313, 314.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old child is brought to the OPD with complaints of persistent delayed developmental milestones, and hyperpigmented macular lesions on the body which are more pronounced on exposure to sunlight. What is the error in DNA multiplication?

A. Base excision repair
B. Nucleotide excision repair
C. DNA mismatch repair
D. Homologous recombination
questions.solution:
• The history points to a diagnosis of xeroderma pigmentosum. It is characterized by defective nucleotide excision repair.
  • UV radiation leads to pyrimidine dimerization in DNA strands, preventing further replication by DNA polymerase.
  • The nucleotide excision repair mechanism corrects the dimer formation in DNA.
  • Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP) is an autosomal recessive genetic disorder characterized by an inability to repair DNA pyrimidine dimers caused by UV exposure. This leads to clinical and cellular hypersensitivity to ultraviolet (UV) radiation.
Reference: Harpar’s illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page No 370.
